name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Silvia Costa, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the implementation of Regulation (EU) no.1295/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, of 11 December 2013, establishing the Creative Europe program (2014-2020) and repealing decisions no.1718/2006 / EC, n.1855/2006 / EC and no.1041/2009 / EC (2015/2328 (INI)) (A8-0030 / 2017).

name: Silvia COSTA
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their great contribution. This is the first time that we have made an implementation report of a multiannual program as Parliament. "Creative Europe" is the only direct program of the European Union for the creative, cultural and audiovisual sector, which today involves 39 countries, with a budget of one and a half billion for the period 2014-2020. A budget that has registered, in these seven years, an increase of 9%, but represents just 0.15% of the European budget. Yet there is some evidence. The European crisis reveals the need for a strong investment in culture and intercultural dialogue and culture-related research. Activities related to cultural heritage are a growing resource for new employment, innovation, skills, social inclusion and cultural tourism. Furthermore, the audiovisual cultural and creative sector now accounts for over 5% of European GDP, which becomes 12% if we include fashion and advertising. The large quantity and quality of the projects presented at "Creative Europe" demonstrates a great vitality of the sector, which however is mainly made up of non-profit entities, small and medium-sized enterprises, cultural institutions and associations, which must be supported and accompanied in the digital challenge in training new skills and fostering cooperation, the mobility of professional artists and cultural products, supporting co-productions, European networks of professionals, strengthening the industrial capacity of the European audiovisual sector and its access to the market, including foreign internationalization of careers. These are the most strategic objectives of "Creative Europe": having brought together the previous "Culture" and "Media" programs under a single program, while keeping them separate, with the addition of a transversal sector has proved useful to give strength and greater visibility to the program and to coordinate governance, but it has not yet produced the results of integration between the different sectors and projects that we expected. Unfortunately, "Creative Europe" suffers from its own success: the ratio of applications submitted and accepted is extremely limited, with a success rate of only 16% for projects in the "Culture" sub-program, and 32% for the "Culture" sub-program. Average". With this implementation report we strongly ask the European Commission and the Member States for a robust integration of funds, in line with the ambitions of the program, but we ask that culture finally becomes the eleventh priority at least in the Commission's program; the word does not appear. The text we are about to vote on asks for: improvements to the management of the program, improvements in the evaluation and evaluation criteria of projects, to make it more accessible, simple, transparent, capable of supporting each sector and therefore being more balanced between sectors, subjects large and small and also naturally the balance between small and large Member States (the participants), giving space to the European ambition to count on the world cultural scene and at the same time to support the creativity of young people, organizations and institutions historical in which we recognize our roots, as well as we appreciated the calls finally addressed also to social inclusion and also to immigrants and refugees. It will be necessary to reorient the program on the quality and artistic value of cultural proposals - and not just economic, as it sometimes seems to prevail - by supporting integration with other programs and opening up to partnerships with non-European countries, especially those bordering the area. Mediterranean and in view of the new strategy for cultural diplomacy and for the European Year of Cultural Heritage, strongly supported by Parliament for 2018. We ask that the current automatisms to safeguard the diversity of European audiovisual production, but enhancing the real production capacity and circulation of audiovisual products as well as greater support for European positions and co-productions in the field, including television, with independent producers, and more access by cinemas film and online distribution. More needs to be done to strengthen the synergies between the "Creative Europe" program and the different multiannual programs, in particular Erasmus + and Horizon 2020. The link between research, innovation and culture is absolutely - and I am happy that Commissioner Moedas is here, because I know it is very sensitive to this issue - but also to innovation in small and medium-sized cultural enterprises. I go to the conclusion. Finally, we are waiting to know the results of the new financial guarantee instrument that we strongly wanted, dedicated to this sector, since the first two European financial institutions have just been selected, and we hope that others can also be selected for cover the European territory in a balanced way, but we ask that the proposal to integrate them with the EFSI be followed up, also using them as front-loading to strengthen the economic and entrepreneurial dimension of the sector.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, next year we will be celebrating, as you know, the European Year of Cultural Heritage. This is a perfect opportunity to bring Europe’s cultural richness into the spotlight and to recall the shared values that connect us and make us stronger. So let me thank this House for its strong commitment to the Year of Cultural Heritage.  The European Year will also be an opportunity to take stock of what the Creative Europe programme is doing for the heritage sector in terms of cross-border cooperation, capacity building and awareness—raising, and more generally the European Year can showcase the positive impact of the programme on Europe’s cultural and creative operators.  Your report comes at a very good moment, at a crucial moment – halfway through the programme’s lifespan when we need to reflect on what we have achieved so far and start work to prepare the future. It is in our common interest to keep a critical eye on how the programme is implemented. I would like to thank Ms Sylvia Costa, as rapporteur, and the shadow rapporteurs for their positive and constructive recommendations. They will all be carefully taken into account in the ongoing mid-term evaluation of the programme.  Let me just make a couple of comments. First, the policy objectives of Creative Europe are to safeguard diversity – and here, as Commissioner for Research, I feel that this is the biggest asset we have in terms of innovation and science and technology, this diversity that your programme safeguards – and make the European cultural and creative sectors more competitive. While these aims remain valid, we are faced with new political and societal challenges such as migration and the rising of populism. Promoting cultural diversity goes hand in hand with opening up cultural participation to more citizens and showcasing our common values with and beyond Europe’s societies.  I am very happy that Creative Europe has proven to be flexible enough to respond to these new challenges. To give you an example, in 2016, following the refugee crisis, we issued a specific call to support cultural projects working to help integrate refugees. At the same time, the number of countries in the EU neighbourhood participating in a programme is growing; negotiations with Israel and Tunisia are underway. This shows the potential of cultural cooperation as a public diplomacy tool in line with the recently adopted strategy of international cultural relations.  Your report calls for strengthening the cross-cultural and the cross-sectoral strength. I could not agree more. Key challenges such as globalisation, the digital transformation, skills development and access to financing are common to all cultural and creative players without undermining the specificities of each sector. We need to find ways to address these challenges in the framework of an integrated programme and reinforce the cross-sectional dimension further. Why? Because today, most innovations are at these cross-sections. We have discovered everything we could at the core of the disciplines. The new things are really at this border and that is one of the fantastic things about your programme.  We are already working on these and let me give you some examples. First, through dialogue with the stakeholders involved. We have been trying to keep abreast of the changing needs of the audiovisual and cultural sectors. Second, our cross-sectoral projects, such as creative hubs, are testing how best to promote innovation and ensure a structuring effect to support industry adaptations to an evolving ecosystem.  Finally, the Guarantee Facility – and you talk about it in your report – that Guarantee Facility is now in operation. It has been very well received with three agreements already signed with financial institutions in France, Spain and Romania, and there are more coming up.  Let me now come to the question of funding. I am fully aware that many high-quality projects cannot be funded due to the programme’s small budget and Ms Costa just mentioned to me before we came in how small the budget is. I am equally aware of the frustration that this creates amongst applicants and potential applicants. As you rightly point out, this is especially relevant for cooperation projects under the cultural sub-programme.  We are trying to address this issue within our room for manoeuver. First, the annual budgets are scheduled to increase until 2020. Secondly, we are thinking about creating a dedicated envelope for smaller cooperation projects – and you talked about it – that would allow us to reach out to new cultural organisations with little experience of working at European level and to involve more grass-roots organisations. Finally, we will continue to make the programme more easily accessible to smaller cultural operators and we are doing so by simplifying our application procedures. Simplifying is essential and is speeding up selection of the decisions by cutting the red tape where possible.  There is only so much we can do, as Ms Costa told me before we came in, with 0.15%, 0.14% of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) currently dedicated to Creative Europe. I am convinced that we can and should do better than that.  Let us be more ambitious for the future. I know I can count on your continued support in this respect, so let us make sure that Creative Europe can truly support and reinforce one of Europe’s greatest assets: its culture.

name: Clare MOODY
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, the Creative Europe programme addresses two of the most fundamental issues that we face today. One is: what are the future jobs going to be? The other is: how in this divisive time do we bring people and communities together? When we look at the possibilities that the digital world of the 21st century will provide for skilled employment, the cultural sector is often rightly cited as the source of jobs long into the future. The new financial instrument aimed at SMEs only deepens the importance of this programme in supporting the growth of this sector.  Beyond the imperatives of growth, there is the separate work of bringing people together. In particular, this programme has now taken on the responsibility of supporting social inclusion for refugees. Ms Costa’s excellent report highlights the strength of this work, but also importantly points to what can be done to improve its delivery. We must ensure it has the resources to fulfil its important role in our society.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! I would like to start by thanking Mrs Costa for her very good report on the implementation of the Creative Europe program and for her exemplary cooperation in the negotiations. We evaluate the first stage of the program implementation as positive. Creative Europe is a relatively small program with broad scope and high ambitions. It confirmed its remarkable success, because as many as 15,000 zlotys were received from the entire EU with a request for funding from European funds. projects. It is therefore very important to increase, as has already been said here, the budget for this program, and this is what we are calling on the Commission and the Member States to do. I also believe that the MEDIA sub-program must focus more on the digitization of film heritage, on partnerships between film schools and on support for professional networks, involving all players in the sector, including authors and writers. Rules for participation in the program should be clearer and more transparent to increase the participation of projects in the Creative Europe program. I believe that it is also important to open a dialogue with the music sector and to give a specific weight to this sector in the Creative Europe program. I also welcome the launch in the second semester of 2016 of the financial instrument and bank guarantees for the creative sector. It is important that this instrument works as quickly and efficiently as possible. This will enable small cultural and creative industries to obtain bank loans of up to EUR 750 million.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today the production of quality content, the ability to innovate, to narrate, to imagine, to excite has become our real raw material and it is a source of employment, as has already been pointed out, especially for young people . "Creative Europe" - Silvia Costa mentioned earlier - is the only direct EU program for the creative, cultural and audiovisual sector. It aims to safeguard and promote cultural and linguistic diversity and cultivate and support the competitiveness of the cultural and creative sectors. A relatively small program, divided, as already mentioned, into two sub-programs "Culture" and "Media", but absolutely strategic, in particular since, I believe also thanks to the stubborn tenacity of the culture committee of the European Parliament, in 2016 it was equipped with a new cross-sectoral financial instrument. An important guarantee instrument, albeit with an objectively contained budget, equal to 121 million euros, and a multiplication factor estimated at 5.7 which, as the Commissioner recalled, has already led to some concrete results. In the first months of this year, agreements were signed to support small and medium-sized industries in the sector in Spain, France and Romania. Unfortunately, the relationship between applications presented and accepted remains the fundamental problem, because it is too limited. The solution passes from a necessary administrative simplification already agreed, but above all from a more adequate increase in the financial endowment, and the reference to EFSI seems obligatory. After the first two years of implementation of this program, therefore, we can say that "Creative Europe" is a fundamental point of reference for European art and culture and it must also be said that it is very popular with thousands of citizens.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Moedas! You should not justify this project with culture, but with science and business. I know beautiful Italian operas, but I don't know any European opera. I read Portuguese literature, but I've never read a book in European language. I like to go to Italian restaurants, but have you ever seen a European restaurant in Brussels? Not me. And I don't know anyone who cheers a European soccer team. Ladies and gentlemen! In my country, culture is a responsibility of the federal states. There is no minister for culture in Germany, and I think that's right. The question is why in this House we have to deal with what is known as European culture. Any attempt to convince the citizens that there should now be a European culture instead of Italian, Portuguese, British, Scottish and Catalan culture is presumptuous in my opinion. There is certainly rich culture in Europe, but there is no European culture. Any attempt to create a European culture here is presumptuous in my opinion. European culture is so diverse because it arises in the countries and in the regions. The attempt to oppose it with a European culture is not multifaceted, but simple-minded.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, there was a sentence in an article in the Guardian about the age of robots which said: ‘If you want a job, you must be as unlike a machine as possible: creative, critical and socially skilled.’ Creativity in the age of the internet is everywhere. People write stories on their blog, they upload songs, they create short videos, and with innovation in robotics and artificial intelligence we will need more and more creative people.  Creativity should not only be supported by the Creative Europe programme, it should be part of every policy, as innovation should be. What is key to creativity, however, is diversity, and Europe has diversity: diversity of languages, of cultures and of history. Therefore, I believe that the Creative Europe programme should also nurture this diversity.  However, when we look at the share of financing that each Member State gets from this programme, most of the funding seems to go to the big five countries with high production capacity and, as I understand it, the same countries want an even larger share of the funding. Therefore I would stress the importance of the Creative Europe programme being open and fair to all creators and all projects, and not just the ones who might, on paper, get the bigger audience and be the most profitable, because this is not what the programme should be about. I also believe that we should stress another point: although Europe is very diverse, consumers’ wishes and behaviour are very similar everywhere. Technology has brought them choice – choice to access content from anywhere, at any time and on any device. No consumer wants to wait for six months or a year to see a movie on TV, and I do not think any creator wishes to limit the amount of people who will see their work. But, by staying stuck in our current models of movie distribution, of financing based on territoriality, and by lacking creativity ourselves in this respect, we are not helping either consumers or creators – maybe only the middlemen in between. The Creative Europe programme should not forget its own name: ‘Creative Europe’. It should support works that will be made widely available and accessible to all European citizens, not only in movie theatres but also online. It should promote innovative financing and distribution models that are not based on territoriality but on EU-wide access, and it should help to create an environment for European online platforms to start up and scale up, because if the idea of our current model is the best one for European creativity, why then do so many movies not even make it into cinemas? This is wrong, as is the idea that only our current model, largely based on territorial exclusivity, is the best one, when online platforms such as Netflix and Amazon have started to finance their own – very diverse and high-quality – content.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The report says: The “Creative Europe” program is a victim of its own success - too many project ideas, too little budget. What does that tell us? Member States' responsibility for culture ensures cultural diversity, and regional culture is ultimately also promoted in other European programs. And yet - Mr Henkel - we also need a European cultural policy that has more than a cat's table on the edge of the European internal market. Our future will not be a shimmering fabric of economic indicators, we will not gain anything with isolationist strategies. But our future depends on our current ability to communicate in many languages, including music and pictures. An intercultural democratic dialogue cannot be taken for granted; it is engraved on Europe's cultural memory. If we want to dispose of these treasures, we have to promote them more. The involvement of the Southern Partnership of Europe must be accompanied much more comprehensively with the “Creative Europe” program. We also need an increase in the “Media” sub-program. Just like chemistry or engineering, film and modern media need good laboratories, space for failed attempts and space for experimentation. For that we need more European publicity. And then the question of an open-minded audience isn't just a question of better marketing. To put it briefly and clearly: Yes, culture costs, but non-culture costs more. And that's why I'm asking for approval.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The first thing I would like to emphasize is that European cultural policy is based on a democratic concept of culture. It is not about a nationalistic concept of culture or an ethnic or even a racist one, but European cultural policy is deeply shaped by being egalitarian. It's about diversity and also about dealing with cultural minorities. Mr Henkel, you are completely on the wrong track if you claim that this is a matter of homogenization or a false restriction, that it is only about European culture. The interesting thing is that it is about the recognition of diversity. It is about promoting this and, of course, enabling artists and citizens to get to know the diversity of European cultures, to benefit from them, to appreciate them, to really know what cultural treasures of diversity there is in the European Union. To say anything else is almost malicious, because the point is to make people understand what opportunities they have with the cultural diversity in the European Union. In particular, I want to recognize that the European creative industry is an essential contribution to this diversity - also to European investment and economic policy. That is why the creative industry must also be an essential part of European economic policy, and this cultural program must above all achieve recognition of the intrinsic value of culture. In the cultural sector in particular, we have many projects that are nonprofit, that do not handle large sums of money, but are able to really radiate into society. Projects that appeal to people on a level that other policies cannot. And this part is so crucial in this European cultural program “Creative Europe”, and that is why it must we strengthen it and not badmouth it or make it small. It is an essential part of a really well-understood European policy that reaches people, in their hearts and in their diversity in everyday life. That is why it is so important to me that the application process is simplified, especially for small projects, because many feel disappointed that they have little opportunity to simply submit these program applications when small sums are involved - a lot can be done there be improved. I would also like to emphasize again - like several colleagues before me - that the cultural budget, as it is now in the European Union, is far too small. With 0.15% of the MFF it does not reflect the real social significance of the diversity of the culture of the European Union. That is why this should urgently be changed when it comes to the next financial perspective. Fortunately, the Commission has started a new project for integration with cultural work for the refugees. We started with a total of 1.6 million. This is better than nothing, but in view of the task that we have here it makes it clear that it is far too small. Therefore, once again my clear petition: The cultural budget of the European Union for securing diversity and the appreciation of diversity must be increased!

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work. The report we are voting on today is a good compromise. In fact, I am convinced that the Creative Europe program, although presenting some critical issues, as a whole must be considered and judged positively. This is especially true with regard to the opportunities it generates for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises and I agree with the request to increase funds for the program. Instead, precisely for this reason, I do not positively judge the transfer of funds, of 3 million euros, which will be carried out for the financing of the European Year of Cultural Heritage in 2018. In fact, I do not believe that this type of operation can be endorsed. and we cannot divert funds from a program that is already largely underfunded. Further points that seem to me worthy of note are, on the one hand, the need to streamline and simplify the bureaucratic procedures for participating in tenders - as many colleagues have already said. In this regard, the request to encourage the use of digital tools is correct. On the other hand, the recognition that the system of performance indicators of the program takes into consideration the creative and artistic aspects, and not just the purely economic ones. We should all consider this recognition to be of crucial importance if we believe in creativity. The creative aspect, to be fully developed and generate quality works, cannot always be subjugated to economic performance. The frantic pursuit of profit at all costs kills creativity. Programs such as Creative Europe are therefore welcome, which aim at forms of public support, always paying attention to forms of abuse.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, I salute the work of the rapporteur, with whom I share certain observations and recommendations for the implementation of the "Creative Europe" program. The report recognizes, in fact, the complexity of the administrative and financial structure, especially for SMEs, and urges the Commission to simplify further, in particular for the application procedures. I also support the rapporteur's recommendations on literary translation projects, which should include the promotion of books and reading, fundamental objectives, in my opinion, not only for the health of our industries but also in their dimension. educational. However, I have reservations on other points. This will not surprise you. You complain about the limited budget, but you do not hesitate to support and want to perpetuate the specific measure in favor of the integration of refugees, the cost of which amounts to 1,600,000 euros. I remind you that it is not for the Member States, nor for European taxpayers, to support your immigration delusions. I would also underline that you have just conceded to the Council and the Commission, during the trilogue for the European Year of Cultural Heritage, that 4 million euros would come from the "Creative Europe" budget out of the 8 million that will cost us in total. this communication operation. With this in mind, I oppose any increase in the program's budget and have tabled amendments to reaffirm that, due to this limited budget, the program should focus on financing European businesses. I am therefore opposed to any further enlargement to third countries. Furthermore, I would like to recall the need to leave the possibility for Member States to keep their cultural exceptions by ensuring that culture remains outside the negotiations of free trade treaties. You will object that it is already the case, but it is always good to remember fundamental principles so that they do not give in to the sirens of the global market.In the end, if I am going to abstain from this report, I cannot help but note with sadness your ability to make even the best of ideas lukewarm.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). - Mr President, unfortunately, the Creative Europe program, despite its beautiful title, is also failing to meet the expectations of Europeans. Instead of creating a real tool that will help to highlight the European culture and rich tradition of our nations, you have essentially built another funding mechanism. Worse still, the participation of dozens of NGOs proves our true fears that culture for you is only what goes with your ideological positions and serves your political interests. You are indifferent both to the distinct, different cultures of our peoples and to their concerns that they are in mortal danger. Regarding the new creation, things get even worse, since everyone knows that in order to support a project, it must present specific political and cultural credentials. Finally, with regard to the inclusion of illegal immigrants, I consider it inappropriate to include such a provision in this program and that it seriously endangers the cultural identity of both Europeans and the illegal immigrants themselves and their countries of origin, and is a covert form. cultural imperialism.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: - Mister President! Dear Colleagues! The “Creative Europe” program with its main sub-areas MEDIA and culture promotes cultural diversity and innovations in cultural and creative projects in Europe and above all cultural exchange between the individual regions. And Mr. Henkel, cultural exchange is what has brought culture in Europe, in every region, forward again and again. Imagine Cologne Cathedral without the development of Gothic in France! I think that perhaps the cultural approach that you have put forward here in a very nationalistic way should be reconsidered. With this program too - just like the next item on the agenda, which we will discuss afterwards - we are confronted with massive underfunding. This also means that the participation of smaller projects in the program areas is insufficient. Here we have to achieve better funding and, above all, to improve and simplify the application process so that small cultural initiatives and projects also have better opportunities to participate in the sub-programs. I also believe it is necessary to ensure greater transparency when a project application is rejected, and for this it is important that a precise and clear justification for the rejection of a project application is given and explained to the applicants. Because that helps reduce the great potential for frustration in the event of a rejection. Furthermore, the cultural and creative industries must be better integrated into other EU funding programs such as B. Horizon 2020, COSME, the European Structural Funds and the EFSI. The first steps to use synergies here have already been taken, but are far from being sufficient, as these funds are not and are not geared towards the specific needs and various structures in the cultural and creative sector adequately address the needs.With the cross-sector action area, in addition to the sub-programs MEDIA and culture, a further funding pillar was created that can be an opportunity for SMEs and micro-enterprises in particular, if the full potential of this action area is actually used and expanded.The cultural and creative sector contributes 4.4% of the EU's GDP and creates jobs for 3.8% of the workforce in the EU.With appropriate funding, the full potential of this industry as a source of growth and employment and as a driving force for cultural diversity and cross-border cooperation could be exploited in the long term.We should all work towards this together!(The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Ms. Verheyen, every Sunday morning I host a jazz program on Radio Jazz Berlin from eleven to twelve - you can listen to that.Jazz also emerged from cultural exchanges between different countries, but there was no Brussels there to make this happen.Do you really think that we need Brussels in order to have cultural exchange?Would you give the same speech in Germany, where we don't even have a minister of culture and also no cultural budget at the federal level?

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. - Perhaps you should first find out a little more clearly. There is a Secretary of State for Culture and he has a budget to match. It doesn't have as much as we would like, but that's always the case in the culture - unfortunately of God - in Europe, especially on the national level. Precisely because many national governments and authorities and ministries are not very interested in promoting cross-border exchange and contact between artists, it is particularly important that we take on this task from the European side and provide support for it here provide that artists and the creative industries can mutually stimulate each other and precisely such things will remain possible in the future, namely that jazz is formed that has mixed together from African and American cultures. We have a lot in Europe that was previously promoted by royal houses and various other structures - only we no longer have the royal houses, and the nation states fail in this area in many places.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, after the German discussion, I would also like to say a few words about the evaluation of the implementation of the Creative Europe program, which is a great opportunity to take stock of the results achieved and to outline the challenges and problems. Within the European Union, this is the only direct program that can benefit the arts, culture and audiovisual sectors. As the rapporteur, Sylvia Costa, rightly pointed out, the program suffers from its own success. The bureaucratic obstacles to applying, together with the low percentage of approved projects due to the lack of financial resources, demotivate cultural figures to apply for funding under the program. If we have to be more specific, the approved projects in the field of Media are equal to 32% of those submitted, and in the field of Culture they are only about 15%. In addition, many proposals are excluded due to the high funding threshold, which is prohibitive for small-scale cultural associations. Europe is known all over the world for its cultural heritage, and the funds set aside for culture amount to only 0.14% of the European Union budget, which is ridiculous to say the least. Speaking of culture and how important it is for the spiritual health and mutual understanding of European citizens, I would like to pay special attention to the mechanism for financing literary translations. Although one of the priorities of the Culture sub-program is the promotion of literary exchange on the territory of the Union, Bulgarian writers dare to say that they are openly discriminated against. In Bulgarian bookstores you can find translations by French or English authors, but at the same time, for example in Belgium, you cannot find a book translated by a Bulgarian author. It is normal for larger and richer countries to have the opportunity to generously support the translation of their writers into other European languages, but this is not the case with us. Readers from other countries too should be able to enjoy the works of writers such as Georgi Gospodinov and Milen Ruskov.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, I would like to talk about this in the context of Brexit. The UK receives more funding than almost any other country through the Creative Europe Programme. Bringing together culture and media programmes is an important part of our membership of the European Union. Although in financial terms it is tiny, this is an area where we actually gain more than we put in. One of the initiatives in this field is the European Capital of Culture. Truro, a city in my own region in the South-West has announced a bid to be the City of Culture in 2023. I understand that the UK Government has been positive about cities making their bids and I understand also that, at this moment, the Commission is sticking to its announcement that there will be two capitals in 2023, one from Hungary and one from the UK. That may change – who knows? – and it may well all become a sidebar in the big negotiation, but the advice for now is to carry on bidding. The UK is still a full and active member of the EU. Having visited other European capitals of culture, most recently San Sebastián in Spain, I have seen at first hand the benefits such a successful bid can bring. However, I would add a note of caution as I would not want to see Cornwall, an area not known for being well off, overspend on a project which is inevitably something of a gamble.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, go raibh maith agat, bhuel ar an gcéad dul síos cuirim fáilte roimh ghnéithe áirithe den tuairisc seo agus aithním cé chomh tábhachtach agus atá sé polasaithe den sórt seo a chur i gcrích. É sin ráite, tá imní orm nach bhfuil an clár ag cur dóthain béim ar an earnáil chultúir agus ag deireadh an lae is iad an chéad ghlúin eile a bheidh thíos leis mar go gcaillfidh siad an saibhreas atá bainteach lenár gcultúr. 1.45 billiún euro thar thréimhse seacht mbliana agus an Coimisiún ag rá linn níos luaithe go mbeidh seans go bhfuil breis airgid ar fáil. Tuigeann an Coimisiún gur éitheach é seo mar ní bheidh an t-airgead sin ar fáil. Ní bheidh sé sa bhuiséad. Tá Brexit ag tarlú mar is eol dúinn ar fad, tar éis 2020 ní bheidh an t-airgead ann chun é seo a chur mar thosaíocht. Ba chóir an fhírinne a insint mar gheall air sin agus gan a bheith ag cur dallamullóg ar dhaoine sa teach seo.  Tá sé soiléir nach bhfuilimid ag cur luach ar ár gcultúr. Feicimid an costas agus cén fáth nach féidir linn an luach sin a fheiceáil chomh maith. Tá luach ann don gheilleagar. Tá luach ann don earnáil chultúir agus tá luach ann i dtaobh fostaíocht a chruthú. Ní hamháin do na ceantair shaibhir ach do cheantair gur minic nach bhfuil acu ach a gcultúr mar ábhar luachmhar. Anois an t-am chun an fhís fhadtéarmach seo a chruthú don earnáil. Go raibh maith agat.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Mr Chairman!As Mr Hans-Olaf Henkel rightly said, there was no European culture.There was Catalan, Castilian, Swabian, Bavarian, Saxon, Czech, English, Scottish culture, and that was the variety.You are all talking about diversity and I think you would like to have diversity, you only entrust it to the officials, and the bureaucracy has to standardize everything by necessity.We used to have Maria Kallas, Edith Piaf, Anna German.Mr. Henkel is wrong - we also have a European culture.It's a shame to say - European culture is represented by Conchita Wurst, because it is understandable to all Europeans.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I would like to emphasize that Creative Europe is in fact the only financial instrument of the European Union that supports creators in the field of art, including audiovisual, and involves cultural institutions and monument managers. Its positives are therefore in the creation of new possibilities for financing joint cultural and artistic projects, it brings together creators, administrators of cultural monuments and institutions. It is not an investment project, building or reconstruction, but an investment in human capital that pays off. Artists have always been people who understood the context and saw the future. Only thanks to them do we have a heritage here that we can look at and listen to hundreds of years after their deaths. Of course, the promotion of culture is primarily the task of nation states. But the role of the European Union is to make better use of the common European space for artists and citizens alike. It is a great motivation and mutual inspiration that we must not waste. The budget is relatively low, mentioning 0.14% of the multiannual financial framework. We could say almost negligible given the wealth that culture provides. But still it has a great response, great interest and we must regret it and must not leave us cold as the low success rate of the culture program is, 15%. What is 15% of those who apply? There is a real threat of demotivation of applicants here. I want to emphasize that we have good experience with contact points in the Member States, it is not about anyone not being able to find out how to draw. On the contrary, the interest is great and the contact points do a good job. Our committee's resolution calls for increased funding and administrative simplification. I think this is not a formal requirement, but that we know why we are asking and what wealth Europe has in culture.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that the creativity, ingenuity, artistic qualities of human capital, that is the great heritage that the history of Europe has consolidated, are the connective tissue that supports that idea of ​​community which must rediscover its growth in the culture of beauty. Culture knows no barriers, it breaks down walls, supports the dialogue between differences, enhances them by intertwining positive feelings, becomes an opportunity to promote economy and quality work. So not just more resources, but a new connection between programs and tools, but also simplification, greater accessibility and a decisive change from overly rigid and formal evaluation criteria, which end up penalizing the most innovative and quality ideas. Innovative ideas which, proposed by an extraordinary network of associations of small and very small enterprises, are very often penalized in the face of the proposals of the obviously better organized and structured industrial system. Culture is an extraordinary opportunity for emancipation, if it orients its languages ​​within a new framework of solidarity, of cohesion between peoples, through the revaluation of the most ancient humanistic traditions of this continent. An opportunity to defeat the xenophobic and racist populist drift that is negatively contaminating Europe. Therefore, the hope is that the tools at our disposal today will be rethought and reoriented also to favor, through cooperation, a new connection between the shores of the Mediterranean.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, respect for the national identity and traditions of the Member States of the Union is a cornerstone for the Europe of the nation-states, for the Europe of the homelands, for the Europe of the peoples. I therefore consider important the fact that 2018 has been declared a year of cultural heritage. The "Creative Europe" program is implemented for the period 2014-2020 and aims to strengthen the European creative sector, in order to promote sustainable and inclusive development within the Union. The Creative Europe program connects culture with creativity and helps the art and creation industry adapt to the digital age. However, the European Union must place more emphasis on countries such as Greece, where the field of culture, innovation and research is affected by the memoranda, is affected by austerity policies, and for this country, funds must be increased. in the fields of culture and innovation.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr President, I want to start by underlining the importance of the Creative Europe program and congratulating Silvia Costa for her work. Culture occupies a very prominent place in Europe and can play a relevant role in the process of European construction, helping citizens to get closer to this process. Now, when there is a certain lack of interest or even distrust of the European process on the part of citizens, we need to do everything possible so that citizens know it better and feel it as their own and as useful. Today's European Union rests on very solid historical and cultural foundations, shared by the European peoples. The European Union is not an artificial construction, nor does it respond only to a movement that emerged after the Second World War, but has very deep roots, and this must be known to European citizens. In this sense, I think it necessary to highlight the importance of the European cultural routes program, launched by the Council of Europe 30 years ago with the proclamation of the Caminos de Santiago as the first European cultural route. Commissioner, we must cooperate closely with this Council of Europe program and help these routes, which seem to me to be a model of cultural cross-border cooperation. These routes have tourist relevance and thus contribute to the development of areas often far from the crowded sun and beach circuit. These routes also serve to preserve the European historical and cultural heritage, so rich and diverse, and to which the very declaration - important declaration - of Bratislava of a few months ago refers. These routes are also very useful to teach Europeans and young people the important historical, cultural, artistic, I would say even spiritual, links that unite us Europeans, thus highlighting the depth and solidity of the foundations of the construction of the city. European Union. As co-chair of the Intergroup of this Parliament for the Development of European tourism, cultural heritage, the Camino de Santiago and other European cultural routes, I ask that this Creative Europe program contribute to the maintenance, improvement, and promotion of the cultural itineraries of the Council ofEurope.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - I would like to begin by appreciating the work of the rapporteur, as her report provides a comprehensive view of the benefits of the Creative Europe program. Culture, the creative industry, these are not only industries that bring us good feelings, experiences, but in fact they are also important for the economy. In today's fragmented Europe, with growing Euroscepticism, it is culture, history and common values ​​that firmly and stably unite European countries. The Creative Europe program financially supports artists and cultural professionals, as well as book translations, the film industry, creates favorable conditions for the mobility of artists and works of art, and raises cultural awareness. I consider the tradition of supporting European cities of culture to be a very successful project. In addition to a number of cultural events, the title Košice - a city of culture in 2013 brought the creation of new jobs to my city where I live, Košice - the largest influx of tourists in history, which has a significant economic benefit and promotion for the city and the state.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Mr President, Colleagues. It is always a pleasure for us to be able to decide, debate and bring about a program that will bring the Union closer to its citizens and have a positive impact on their lives. The Creative Europe Program is exactly one such framework program, which aims to promote culture and creativity across Europe, unfortunately underfunded. I would like to highlight two aspects of this, let me allow it. In the minority working group I co-chaired, we have already dealt with projects under this program on several occasions, as well as with the European Capitals of Culture. The experience is that these projects can play an important role in the life of traditional national and linguistic minority communities, in preserving their identity and promoting the coexistence of the majority minority. We must continue to support these projects in this regard. The other element that I would highlight, emphasizing the importance of European cultural and creative networks, is the issue of nurturing European talent. Building on the Hungarian example, there is now a very strong European talent support network in the EU. It helps you discover talents as well as develop and nurture them. This is an area that we need to pay special attention to and allow those concerned to have access to the right EU funding, because talent is like a natural resource and its support is an investment in the future.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, juggling, hula-hooping and spinning plates is not something I would normally do as an MEP, but last week I swapped debating in this Chamber for trying out circus skills. I was in Great Yarmouth, in my constituency, to visit Sea Change Arts. Their director told me how the EU projects that they have taken part in have been transformational, in terms of both the money they received and the relationships built. They are now one of the leading international organisations for street arts and circus. I know some of my political opponents get into a spin about EU projects, but I can see the true legacy of Britain’s membership of the EU in events like Great Yarmouth’s popular Out There festival. EU policy has played a significant role in creating and nurturing a vibrant cultural and creative sector across Europe. Long may it continue.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: - Mr President, the Creative Europe program for the period 2014-2020 is undoubtedly the most ambitious to date, both in content and form, but in those three years of execution, several shortcomings of the program have been observed. The Committee on Culture has highlighted these issues in the report and we urge the Commission to act as soon as possible. There are a number of priorities that the Commission should pursue. First, it should outline the intersectoral chapter: the Commission must verify its usefulness and operation, since the sectors complain of lack of access to credit. The audiovisual sectors operate in very competitive environments and we must give our creators the necessary tools to continue producing quality pieces. Furthermore, the Commission should coordinate and strengthen the Creative Europe offices in participating countries to facilitate access for creators, create synergies and thus improve the use of resources. And thirdly, and despite the 9% increase, the budget allocated to this program must be increased to allow the further development of a plural and diverse culture within the European Union and neighboring countries. Furthermore, the countries of the southern neighborhood, which are not part of the program, should be urged to join this space of cultural diversity and opportunities. We must continue betting on European culture: our cinema, our music, our literature, our artists. It is essential to support these sectors, facilitating financing, training and discussion: this is the greatest wealth we have.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Culture is not covered by Community policy and I want to make it clear that this is good. I am not in favor of extending the competences of the European institutions to include culture. On the other hand, with regard to the Creative Europe program, I would like to say three things that are crucial. First of all, this program should be as bureaucratic as possible and I am very pleased with the declarations made today. Secondly, decisions should be made much faster because this slow decision-making process, in short, harms the program. And the third key point: in the "Creative Europe" program there is an opportunity to use current digital technologies to make it highly effective in connection with, for example, scholarship programs such as Erasmus +. I would like to thank Ms Silvia Coście, who ended her term as chairman of the Committee on Culture, because some things happened. First, we do indeed have a slightly less bureaucratic program. Secondly, the arrears in payments have finally been eliminated. And the third thing: the declarations made today are the result of the work of the entire committee to ensure that this program, along with the pilot programs, is a complement to the various other tools that we are using.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I welcome the fact that the report specifically mentions: among the projects funded under the Creative Europe Program, the number of projects promoting cultural diversity, intercultural dialogue and multilingualism will hopefully increase after 2017. The rapporteur justifies this with the significant influx of migrants and refugees into the Union. Without questioning the importance of this, I would like to point out that these aspects should have been an important part of the program so far. Not only because of the migrants or the EU citizen with a significant migration background, but also because of the EU citizen belonging to an indigenous national minority of around 60 million. The promotion of cultural diversity and multilingualism is necessary not only because new minorities are emerging in the EU, but also because, for centuries, national communities living in the same area have meanwhile become minorities in the territory of a Member State. And we can support these minorities with low financial capacity in preserving their language and culture by paying special attention to minority projects, including financial support, in addition to increasing the budget for cultural programs.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all my colleagues who have worked on this report from the outset. I am surprised by the position of some colleagues, I would call it a selfish position because here we are not talking about the destruction of national culture, we are talking about a united Europe in diversity and in my career I was Minister of Tourism and SMEs and I saw how much there is between them. fields and culture. Culture actually creates bridges between our countries, we know each other better and that's why I consider it necessary to finance the cultural act because around any cultural objective - my country has a very rich heritage, around it develops the creative industry, SMEs- hats, jobs. It surprises me once again what my colleagues say and I ask them: if they had a neighbor, house by house, about whom I don't know anything, I don't know what they do, I don't know what they do, I don't know what their habits are, they would be more safe than if they knew what that man next to them was doing? I support and, Commissioner, consider the funding proposal because here we are talking about a culture with radial effects in all areas of activity and I hope it is understood that Europe can be united if we know our values, cultural heritage, traditions and, I take the opportunity to say that yesterday in Romania was celebrated March 1, the symbol of creative art - here is this symbol, creative art.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr President, more than 8.5 million jobs in the European Union are in the culture and creative industries, which account for a total of 4.5% of GDP.Employment in these sectors is growing at an average of 3.5% per year.That is why the "Creative Culture" program is crucial for creating new jobs and helping artists, cultural professionals for European film, music, heritage preservation, but also the video game industry.The exchange of experiences and knowledge is crucial, as well as connecting member states.We need to make Creative Europe more visible and present among our citizens, because it is a program that makes a difference, encourages European innovation and positions us as leaders who surprise with ideas and creativity, who shape the future but on the basis of their cultural heritage and tradition.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, creativity and collaboration across borders are even more important in these days of extreme nationalism and xenophobia. The arts and culture touch us all as human beings, providing a unique and powerful means to change hearts and minds, to promote self-confidence and community cohesion, and to help people live together as good neighbours in an increasingly complex and frightening world.  The great city of Liverpool in my Northwest England constituency, a diverse city built on migrant labour by the way, was saved from obscurity through its designation as a Capital of Culture in 2008, delivering a world-class programme with a lasting legacy, contributing to the local tourism economy and its wealth of entrepreneurs. I can tell you, as somebody who worked in the arts before politics, that the Creative Europe programme, including in its previous incarnation, has been and still is of great interest to British artists and arts organisations, and that the tragedy of Brexit was not the choice of the people of Liverpool nor the wish of the wider arts and media community or their audiences across the whole of the UK, who voted overwhelmingly to stay in the EU and work together with their neighbours.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all congratulations to Mr Costa on his excellent report. The "Creative Europe" program has proved useful in anticipating new trends in relevant sectors, linking culture and creativity, promoting the circulation of young talented artists, audience development in the digital single market ecosystem, and online with the 2005 Unesco Convention, cultural diversity at the international level. "Creative Europe" has set objectives, has adopted a series of evaluation criteria, but has neglected the artistic quality of the creative and cultural proposals without which art risks becoming purely commercial. In this way, the program would end up rewarding those who follow the prescribed format, instead of trying to discover true quality. I hope that the promotion of cultural quality and the intrinsic value of culture will be included in the evaluation criteria and objectives of the legal basis of the post-2020 program. The mid-term review will have to strengthen training, public development, market access and social inclusion, in anticipation of the new program for the period 2021-2028.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). - Mr President, we support the Creative Europe program because it is a program that supports culture and Europe has a strong foundation in culture. However, I believe that Europe 's primary task is to support and preserve and protect its own cultural heritage. The Cypriot cultural heritage is at the same time European. The European Union is well aware that for 43 years, on a huge piece of Cypriot territory, 37% of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus, the cultural and religious heritage of Europe has been destroyed on a daily basis. Commissioner, we consider and appreciate the work you are doing, that it is time to take the initiative, as a huge, important part of the religious cultural heritage and treasures in occupied Cyprus is being destroyed at the moment, so that there are ways to preserve what is the most important and the main thing, to finance programs that will allow us to restore what the Turkish occupier destroyed. Of course, a clear message must be sent to Turkey as well. It cannot be a member country and at the same time, the one that wants to join the European Union, destroy the cultural heritage of the European Union and trade these treasures. I believe that the time has come for action and we hope and believe and rely very much on you, Commissioner.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, last but not least, I welcome the success of the programming objectives of promoting European cultural diversity and strengthening the potential of the cultural and creative sector, although it is important to call strongly for an increase in the seriously under-financed Creative Europe budget in order to bring it into line with expectations. I believe we must continue to support the cultural, creative and audiovisual sector strongly, asking for an increased budget for the programme, both to meet expectations and to avoid frustration, together with better management of the existing programme, with more transparency and simplified procedures. The creation of three new strands, on innovative crossovers, social inclusion and Creative Europe Mundus, to include third countries, will feature in our objectives and priorities. We have to make Europe first.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for this very interesting debate and for all the ideas that came out of the discussion.  I think everyone talked about diversity. Everyone used that word as something that we should really cherish and I think that, more than ever, we need in Europe a creative and cultural programme.  As Commissioner for Innovation and as someone who lived abroad for a long time, firstly I believe deeply that we have a European culture and those of you who, like me, have lived abroad felt that every day when you lived outside of Europe. You feel that you have a culture that is different to others because it is a culture of diversity, because you think differently, you feel differently, because you are more intolerant of inequality, because you feel yourself, when you are abroad, that you are closer to your European friends.  I lived for years outside of Europe and most of my friends were always Europeans because we speak that language of diversity, of understanding others. I think that it is very important to realise that, even with that diversity of languages, we are so close, much closer than you might think, and especially when you live abroad, as I have lived.  The second point that came from the discussion that is essential is that innovation comes from these intersections – these intersections of disciplines, these intersections of science and art and music – and so many of you here referred to that. In 2015 I was at the Nobel Prize Award Ceremony and the person who won the Nobel Prize for Medicine was a woman called Tu Youyou. This woman is not a medical doctor; it is a very interesting fact that most of the Nobel Prizewinners are not specialists in their own field. They come from other fields. They come from those intersections.  Tu Youyou saved millions of people because she discovered a cure for malaria. She discovered that cure for malaria because she was reading a poem in a book that was more than 1 700 years old. By reading that poem she found a plant called Artemisia and then she found through that poetry how she could extract that plant, Artemisia, in a way that would save people. She found this cure that has saved millions of people and I think that that is the future – the future is this cross between culture and science and art. If we want to be at the edge, if we want to be at the best that technology does, that science does, we have to be at these borders of culture and arts and science.  Thank you so much for the very interesting debate. It was a great place to be this morning, listening to all of you, believers in Europe and believers in this programme, as I am.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: rapporteur. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very happy with this beautiful debate in which so many colleagues have generously participated and I also thank them for the words they have had towards me and I am very grateful to Commissioner Moedas' real attention. I fully agree with this emphasis that you have made: innovation is now increasingly placed in the ability to integrate between the various sectors, between the various languages ​​and also between the different disciplines. I think this is the challenge for the second part of the seven years for "Creative Europe" which on this front must do much more, but I believe it is an internal problem, but also an external one. If we talked about it before, we absolutely must achieve - as we have requested - greater transversal attention, also of the different DGs and of the different competences so that, with Erasmus +, with Horizon 2020, with the structural funds, more integrations are initiated and we naturally ask for a serious and important of the budget. You have heard that all colleagues were talking about the frustration of so many cultural workers who will eventually tire of proposing - this is terrible, at a time like this, of the crisis we are experiencing in Europe, which is a cultural crisis; it would be strange if culture was finally not put at the top of the Juncker program. The second evaluation - I cannot answer all of them, but I collect some of the most important and common questions - there has been a dilemma between diversity and unity and has accompanied Europe since its birth, it is clear that cultural policy is not a community policy but cultural policy is based on the treaty in two respects: enhancing and supporting cultural and linguistic diversity and, on the other, enhancing and protecting the common European cultural heritage. Therefore, diversity in unity is the figure of Europe and even when we talk about European cultural diplomacy, on which we are committed, we speak always also to make known how it was possible to live in a dimension of peace in this continent, precisely because diversity and dialogue have led to the possibility of peaceful coexistence, innovation and inclusion. This is the challenge of culture under all skies. So there is no contradiction. Then I would like to say that the roots of Europe are in music, philosophy, thinkers, spirituality, creativity, theater, literature and all the greatest have been in all countries those who have not closed themselves in small homelands. , but who have dialogued with the world, who have tried to understand, everything has intertwined in the history of European culture, it would be truly shortsighted not to recognize this. We therefore want with this program, we demand what? In the meantime, greater attention is paid to this integration of sectors; second: to have a greater attention to the evaluation criteria - everyone came and I agree - that of having criteria that evaluate more the artistic merit and also the intrinsic cultural merit of the projects. I think it is right now to claim that these new loans that are given through loans, as a financial instrument, should not be reserved for those accredited financial situations, only for the countries where they reside but are made to support European projects - it must be very clear this - otherwise it would be an imbalance. And last thing - time is a tyrant - cultural networks, it is very true, we want to support more the European cultural networks that are those that cross Europe, the cultural itineraries and the European capitals of culture that have celebrated their 30th anniversary their establishment. We asked to evaluate them as extraordinary results, because in many cities, which were also in industrial crises - as we said before, Liverpool has been relaunched thanks to being the capital of culture and this has led to a rethinking of the city, more focused on culture.I close on the Brexit issue, I just say a word, I cannot fail to mention it: I believe that - of course, the English colleague said - England has had more than it has given in culture also because it has a lot of cultural wealth.However, I must say that the preconditions for continuing to participate in "Creative Europe" are clear, they are to accept at least the four fundamental freedoms of movement of people, of capital, and so on.So, this is going to be the battle for the British citizens, not us.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you, Mr Costa, congratulations on your work and congratulations also on the work of the rapporteurs of all the parliamentary groups.The discussion is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday 2 March 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - First of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague Silvia Costa, the rapporteur, for her excellent work. The Creative Europe Program is making a growing intercultural space accessible to many, and it is the only program that supports cultural diversity. I am extremely pleased that the program is flexible enough to respond to new challenges. I believe that the program must pay particular attention to expanding the budget and create a separate pillar for small and medium-sized enterprises so that their actions can be fully exploited. Small organizations often do not have enough financial resources to start projects, so it should be emphasized that the program should be fair to everyone. Parliament is calling for a review of these procedures in order to encourage as many organizations as possible to apply. There is a need to speed up final payments as well as better coordination between programs, as this can also help to leverage other resources.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up. - In an increasingly competitive landscape of international cinema, the European audiovisual sector still needs support measures to protect its diversity and independence, on the one hand, and to protect and preserve Europe's audiovisual heritage, on the other. other side. Through the digitization of films and audiovisual archives, this heritage can and must be made available for the purpose of research, public involvement and economic exploitation. I therefore consider it beneficial to continue to provide direct support for European audiovisual production, especially in the project development phase. In addition, there is a need to expand vocational training in various fields and activities, in order to include more actions and strengthen the competitiveness of the sector. At the same time, I believe that it is beneficial for Europe to strengthen actions aimed at promoting European works across borders and carrying out joint creative projects with non-EU countries, but also to develop projects to mobilize the European public to increase demand for non-EU European films. national.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - The European Union's cultural and creative sector must be supported, not only because it has been shown to create a significant percentage of jobs, but also because preserving our identity is the foundation on which the EU is built. However, we are facing unprecedented challenges and therefore we must learn to prioritize the most important things. We don't always have to start by asking for more money to be more efficient. Existing funds must be used effectively before new requests for more funds are made. Investments should be directed in the right areas. Creative Europe has aspects for improvement, and that is what we need to focus on. For example, I still have doubts about the good governance of the program given the fact that it is managed by individual directorates - decision-making in these cases is complex and not always consistent. Such approaches, in my opinion, should be avoided, as we strive for efficiency and results.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: in writing. - The Creative Europe Program is the only direct EU program for the creative, cultural and audiovisual sectors, and it is necessary to support and ensure the continuity of its work and projects, with a stronger focus on reducing social exclusion and innovative cross-benefit and cross-sectoral projects. I would urge you to look not only at the strict formal requirements when assessing applications, but also at the content of the projects submitted. It is important to ensure clearly regulated, transparent project delivery and funding. There is a need to increase funding for this cultural program, as interest and expectations from developers far exceed the program budget. The development of application and project implementation skills of cultural operators should also be borne in mind. Culture is a sensitive part of the lives of the people of the European Union. It is important both for the cultural expression and individuality of national identity and for openness to other cultures and their diversity. European identity is not just a synthesis of national cultures, the ultimate goal of which is the common denominator of European identity. Culture is a living, ongoing process, accompanied by new discoveries and challenges. One is how to reconcile the influence of the economic dimension with the intrinsic value of art and culture and focus more on artists.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: signed up.- I welcome the proposals to increase the resources allocated from the budget of the European Union and the budgets of the Member States for culture.Europe has a competitive advantage by highlighting the huge historical cultural heritage, as well as the new cultural trends developed in Europe today.If in manufacturing production we have strong competitors in Asia and other parts of the world, in the creative industry we have this competitive advantage, which we can maintain, continuously upgrade and bear fruit.That is why a smart industrial policy cannot ignore the support of governments and the Union for Culture.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by María Teresa Giménez Barbat, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the implementation of Regulation (EU) no.390/2014 of the Council, of 14 April 2014, establishing the "Europe for Citizens" program for the period 2014-2020 (2015/2329 (INI)) (A8-0017 / 2017).

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: speaker. - Mr President, dear Commissioner, dear President, dear colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking all my colleagues from the Committee on Culture and Education, who have worked with me in a great spirit of cooperation and mutual understanding on this report addressed to the implementation of the Europe for Citizens program. The Europe for Citizens program is the only one of the European Commission that aims to encourage the direct participation of citizens in the Union and promote dialogue between institutions, civil society organizations and local administrations. For this reason, we have asked the Culture Commission for an increase in the budget of the program so that the objectives set can be achieved. First of all, it should be remembered that the budget agreed for this program for the 2014-2020 period was significantly reduced, 14% compared to the previous period. In Parliament and in the Committee on Culture and Education we have been requesting an increase in the budget, with the figure of 500 million euros to be able to adequately satisfy the project proposals that reach the evaluation agencies. Furthermore, if we compare it with the budget of the Erasmus and Creative Europe programs, which we have discussed now, it is clear that it is necessary to provide this program with a greater financial effort. Secondly, we have asked the Commission to develop a more innovative communication strategy. It is essential that this program can become better known in Europe. Unlike others, Europe for Citizens is not as popular and participation is very low among non-governmental organizations, foundations dealing with matters related to European citizenship, city councils and networks of regions and cities that are their recipients. We need to have a more efficient and accessible platform, which allows knowledge depth of available funds and a strengthening of relations with the contact points of the Member States. We hope that all organizations and local administrations know in detail the possibilities offered by this program and that participating countries that have not yet done so designate a national point of contact. Thirdly, we believe that the European memory area of ​​the Europe for Citizens program should take into account not only Europe's past and memory, but also its future. We intend to convey a historical account that is not obsessed with differences, but rather tries to overcome them in a spirit of integration. We believe that this project will contribute to forming a more optimistic and integrated vision of Europe, with a view to forging a common future. Last but not least, the report unambiguously states that the next generation of the program should be adopted under the ordinary legislative procedure, putting Parliament on an equal footing with the Council. I wish to underline that, as the only Union institution directly elected by the citizens, the European Parliament must play its role as the Union's co-legislator when it comes to adopting a program specifically created with the aim of encouraging citizen participation. Therefore, in my report, I urge the Commission to find a suitable legal basis for the next generation of the program, allowing the European Parliament to truly participate in the process of adopting and implementing this program. For this reason, dear colleagues, I ask you to support the report, as approved by the committee.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr. President, my colleague Commissioner Avramopoulos sends his regrets but has asked me to say a few words on his behalf. Honourable Members, the Europe for Citizens programme offers a unique platform to reach out to citizens and to engage them in a debate about the future of Europe. In the year of its tenth anniversary as a fully-fledged programme with its own identity, the Europe for Citizens programme is well established. Stakeholders and beneficiaries appreciate it as one of the most relevant means to involve citizens in shaping their – that is, our – European Union. Projects funded by the programme will now also offer placements for the European Solidarity Corps. This will allow young Europeans to put their civic engagement into practice fully in line with the objectives of the programme.  This is why I am glad that the European Parliament has prepared this implementation report on the programme, which looks back at the first three years. I would like to thank Parliament, and in particular the rapporteur Ms Giménez Barbat, for the commitment and the effort that you have put into preparing this report, which not only gives an overview of the programme’s implementation, but will also be an important starting point for the mid-term evaluation that we are currently preparing. It will provide some first orientations for a new citizenship programme beyond 2020.  Let me stress the elements of your report, which we shall have the chance to reflect on jointly in the near future. First, as you mentioned, the budget. Under the current Multiannual Financial Framework this has been a major challenge for the Europe for Citizens programme. Participation in the programme has become very competitive and success rates have decreased to very low levels in some measures, and we need to look at that. Second, the streamlined structure of the current programme, with the two strands focusing on European remembrance and on democratic engagement and civic participation, works well. It is positive, allowing for a more focused approach and increasing the programme’s impact. Last, but by no means least, the issue of the legal base which you raise that could enable the European Parliament to get involved in the adoption of a new programme as co-legislator. In view of the mid-term evaluation, let me assure you that the Commission seeks the strongest possible cooperation with this House on both the political direction and the implementation of the Europe for Citizens programme over the four remaining years and of course looking ahead beyond 2020.  In conclusion, can I just acknowledge the European Parliament’s important role in both preparing and assessing the current Europe for Citizens programme.
