We are only at the beginning of our cooperation to give new momentum to this programme. The Commission looks forward to continuing to work with Parliament towards our common objective: to encourage the maximum participation of our citizens in building the European Union of the future.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. - Mr President, I firmly believe that programs such as the Europe for Citizens program, of which I have the honor of drafting the opinion of the Committee on Budgets, are programs that are truly harmonized and follow the same line of purpose. that we have set here, that is, to serve the European idea, the European principles, the European values. That, I believe, was the spirit of the European Commission President Juncker's own speech on the White Paper on the Future of the European Union. If we really want Europe to have a future, at a time when Euroscepticism and populism are sweeping through everything, then we must support and strengthen programs such as Europe for Citizens. It is a program that touches on citizens, that reaches out to civil society, a program that promotes a Europe truly at the service of citizens. At the same time, however, it is a program whose 185 million budget cannot meet the needs and requirements of society today. If we really want to strengthen the European institution, the European ideas and the European principles, we have to do one thing: to shield and strengthen similar programs, such as the one we discussed earlier, for Creative Europe, the Europe for the citizens "," Erasmus + ". I believe that we need to coordinate them and plan in such a way that they really serve the people and society, in order to really create a Europe for the future.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. - Mr Chairman! Colleagues! The Committee on Constitutional Affairs highly appreciates the shape and implementation of this program. In our opinion, we present a few remarks - I will summarize them in three main points. Firstly, to raise the profile of those projects that concern European remembrance and civil society. Secondly, the openness of the program itself to citizens, that is, greater participation of states and local authorities in defining priorities, bringing the national contact points closer to make the program more known, removing language barriers in the project submission process. The third issue is opening the program to countries outside the European Union, EFTA countries, EEA countries and candidate countries to the European Union. We believe that the program should be open and build real ties with neighboring countries. We also join this proposal, which assumes a stronger role for the European Parliament, a clear legal basis and the participation of the European Parliament in defining the program priorities. These are the key recommendations of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: , on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Teresa Giménez Barbat, for the excellent work carried out and the good cooperation in the preparation of this report. In the current situation in the Union - as we well debated yesterday - of rampant nationalisms, populisms and euroscepticisms, we cannot sit idly by: we have a responsibility to combat them. The best way to do this is by involving citizens, bringing them closer to the Union. To this end, it is essential to help improve understanding of the Union, its history and its diversity. The evaluation report of the Europe for Citizens program demonstrates the success of these programs in the medium and long term in combating these phenomena. This initiative is still young and little known, but the number of applicants for funds reflects the interest that citizens have in getting involved with the European project: the quality of the projects presented is a good sign of this. Sadly, many of those projects have gone empty-handed. This is due to insufficient funding. In the last financial framework - the rapporteur has said it - funding was reduced by 14%. It is not that the projects were not worth it, but that there were not enough funds for so many projects. We must be more ambitious when it comes to contributing to a better understanding of the European Union, its history and its diversity by citizens. I ask the Commission to increase the budget to a minimum of EUR 500 million, which is necessary to ensure the success of the program. Europe for Citizens will not be the answer to all problems, but it will contribute substantially to bringing citizens closer to the European project.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to congratulate my colleague María Teresa Giménez Barbat on her work. In an area like this, cooperation with political groups and listening are essential to produce an ambitious report and to give new impetus to the "Europe for Citizens" program. This is a fundamental process, as Europe is attacked by nationalism and Euroscepticism and experiences a sharp rise in intolerance, which challenges the sense of belonging to a common space. What are our priorities? They were recalled by my colleagues. In my opinion, there are four of them. First, the question of the budget. I believe that we have to send a very clear message: we want a substantial increase in the means made available to this program, which very directly concerns European citizens. This program is still based on too limited an envelope. It is not normal, in particular, to have such a low rate of acceptance of files. Not changing would mean discrediting this program among the most committed citizens, and that is why we have asked to increase this budget to 500 million euros, or ultimately one euro per citizen. Then on the legal basis. We want to be clear: the European Parliament as an institution representing European citizens cannot be absent from the legislative process, so a legal solution must be found, it is non-negotiable, I believe. The third priority is the need for more active communication. In the digital and social media age, it is important that the program can be more visible on the web and be represented in a non-bureaucratic and above all more educational discourse. This program must also reach new audiences, young people in particular, whose civic engagement is well known, in particular at the time of the European elections. We must therefore go beyond the somewhat rigid or a little too traditional formats of public meetings by developing more dynamic projects, which make it possible to share experiences. Finally, to be accessible, the procedures of this program must be simplified. Efforts must focus on small project leaders and involve more, in the definition of priorities, civil society, which is certainly well placed to reflect the concerns of citizens. This program should support the participation of a wider range of audiences, including vulnerable people, who should receive additional assistance. In addition, we must continue to encourage initiatives recognized for their success, such as town twinning. In the hostile climate that Europe is going through, this program must serve as a point of support to relaunch the European project among citizens committed to a strong Europe and in a reaffirmed spirit of solidarity.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Mr. President, the European Union is really in a crisis that we will find very difficult to overcome if we do not put this community in a realistic framework in which it will solve only those problems for which it has the capacity and respect the principle of subsidiarity. Such programs do just the opposite - they raise the European Union to the level of an omnipotent creation that re-educates citizens, instills new identities in them and interferes in all spheres of society and life. The report recommends that the European Memory sub-program develop a European identity that should be plural, transcultural and open to migratory flows and influences from the rest of the world. Apart from the fact that I do not see any need to create artificial identities, I must admit that it is not clear to me what kind of identity it would be if it was based only on the political ambitions of European elites and the needs of one political moment. Those citizens who primarily feel European, feel that way because, despite our heterogeneity, there is a lot that unites us, and that is primarily Judeo-Christian values. They are not mentioned here, although Europe as it is today would not exist without them. It is interesting that such a recommendation is to be realized within the sub-program "European Memory". If my memory serves me well, communist Yugoslavia also created artificial identities and promoted values ​​that had no basis in tradition. It ended ingloriously, and it was brought down by generations whose brains were systematically brainwashed. We could learn something from that.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: , on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I want to congratulate the rapporteur for this report because I share the need to increase the budget for the Europe for Citizens program. It is enough to remember that, in some of its most important sections, such as historical memory, it only finances 6% of applications, not due to a lack of quality in citizen proposals, but exclusively due to lack of money. I also share, and have tried, that the contact points of each State help to better understand the program to its potential beneficiaries. And I say this because amnesia is playing a very trick on us. The same populist and ultra-nationalist ideas that signed the greatest catastrophes in our history are now presented as false solutions to our great problems. For this reason, we should devote more imagination, interest and resources to remembering what results these recipes reaped, to put before the mirror of our history some regrettable speeches that are in tune with the harangues that justified and fostered our past tragedies, and to underline that the European Union was the effective and useful response to that language of selfishness, lack of solidarity, war, violence and poverty. That is why I am asking for more funds and, therefore, I am happy that, after a series of initiatives led by several Members, all European totalitarian regimes are joining Nazism or Stalinism, the first objective of this program to be able to recover our memory. That is why I am glad that the 80th anniversary of the Spanish Civil War is included among the eligible activities to fund activities in favor of truth, justice and reparation. Because, eighty years after the bombing of Gernika, one of the two states involved in that massacre, a member of the European Union, still does not recognize its responsibility and ask for forgiveness for those events. Because today that same State does not collaborate with universal justice to investigate and punish all the crimes of the dictatorship, actions that, as the report very well recalls, would make it very difficult for someone with this behavior to enter the European Union today.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my group had voted against "Europe for citizens", I will vote in favor of this report on the basis of a pragmatic assessment: this program worked, this program involved citizens, associations that deserved to have a voice and to participate - participation is the key to the salvation of the Union and this program encourages citizen participation. If I look at the list of funded programs, I see very positive things in my country: the fight against the mafia, Roma associations - Roma are a great European people of 12 million inhabitants who are not represented here and who are at the center of a series of discrimination. However, I agree with the rapporteur both on the issue of insufficient funding and on another very important issue, which is the legal basis; it is paradoxical that a program that aims to involve citizens limits the role of the European Parliament, which is the only key for citizens to participate by electing representatives. Therefore, it would be important to change this legal basis and also allow us to help a better formulation of objectives, which remains very weak, in some cases clumsily ideological, for example, equating criticism of Europe with Euroscepticism is absurd. The real pro-Europeans today can only be very critical.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! "Europe for Citizens" - the title makes it clear what it is about. It is a program that is aimed directly at the citizens and wants to give them additional opportunities to implement good ideas, realize projects together and work together across borders. This program has two main focuses. The first point is culture of remembrance. As we know from current disputes, this is a point that is extremely important in the European Union in particular, it is about coming to terms with the history of Stalinism, National Socialism and Fascism and thereby really contributing to a democratic society that is One is able to deal with difference and minorities in a positive way and not have to exclude these people. The second point is democratic citizen participation. This, too, is an area that is about the quality of democratic life in the European Union, where citizens have the opportunity to participate in town twinning or if they have special ideas - some examples have already been mentioned - to receive targeted funding in order to implement joint projects in the European Union. The problem is, however, that this budget is so small that it cannot live up to the claim that is being announced. It's even worse: the budget has even been slashed with the last multiannual financial framework now running. So really absurd in a situation where the Commission and Parliament are right to say: We have to do more with this program in particular, because we can see from the number of applications that there is a very great need and that the citizens need it Accept the program because it really gives them additional options. So what's the job?We must work specifically to increase the budget for this program so that we can actually put into practice the aim of additional opportunities for cooperation and real development from below in terms of European citizenship and European citizens' projects.So with the next MFF there must be a clear change here, and that is what the citizens will give us really high credit for, in terms of participation and democratic participation.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, "Europe for citizens" would be a program with a high symbolic content, since it aims at developing a common sense of European identity and solidarity, but today it must make us reflect on the causes of the loss of credibility of this European Union. Beyond the good numbers and good results that have taken place over the years, in the part relating to the priority of the program and among the compromise amendments that have been voted on, we read in fact: understanding and debating euroscepticism. Well, at least, there is a need to accept the Eurosceptic phenomenon as a fact of the reality in which we live. An example above all, of course, is what is happening today with Brexit, which calls into question the existence of a European project. However, I strongly doubt that the Eurosceptic phenomenon can be debated in this way. To make myself better understood, I give the example of the political reality of my country. Italians have always been counted among the Euro-enthusiasts, but in recent years they too have progressively distanced themselves and have begun to look at Europe with a disenchantment that is increasingly growing. This happened for various economic, identity, political reasons and for lack of democratic participation. What is at stake today is the very ability of public institutions to respond to the legitimate questions that citizens ask political authorities and institutions themselves. For this reason, in the report, we asked the Commission and the Member States to strengthen the link between the priorities of the program in question and all policies, first of all, social and employment policies. Europe has long been considered a sort of lifeline but today, without direct participation, we are no longer credible.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Thank you, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Europe for Citizens program is the only European program that addresses all the citizens of Europe directly, through the four funding lines. I would point out that the field of culture, the one that must develop the unity in diversity of the Union's motto, is perhaps the most difficult, if we consider the financing and, implicitly, the importance given to it. The report on the implementation of the Europe for Citizens program is relevant and in line with reality. Perhaps the only observation is that the report is too uncritical. The problems mentioned are acute: regionalization of projects, isolation of eccentric countries, unfavorable lump sums in many cases, canceled priorities of no interest to some countries, low pre-financing in general, and lack of pre-financing for twinning. In Romania, in 2014 and 2015 the number of applications increased a lot, reaching about 3,000 projects submitted by each deadline. Unfortunately, due to underfunding, less than 10% is funded from them, which obviously leads to a growing lack of interest in the program. The lack of interest of the operators increases even more due to the reduced financing on the project. Thus, the maximum funding is EUR 150 000 thousand per project for two of the funding lines, much less for the others. From the information I have, the national contact points want to extend their responsibilities after the submission of projects because they are asked for information after this time and, in addition, relationships are created with applicants and we do not want to disappoint them. The national contact points also want to know the selection procedure, how the evaluators work, how the scores are awarded and, in general, they want more transparency and cooperation. In addition, the Romanian National Contact Point wants a different relationship with the Commission European and the Education, Audiovisual and Culture Executive Agency on a partnership basis, the current relationship is almost humiliating because these contact points are the link between the European institutions and applicants and thanks to them the program is promoted.The European Union spends a lot of resources not only money but also time or human resources in areas that favor globalism, uniformity and multinational companies.By contrast, culture, education and, above all, projects for citizens are a kind of cinderella.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, it is questionable how a report on the Europe for Citizens program has a prominent place and constantly mentions Euroscepticism and immigration. Some parts of the exhibition can not be left unattended. First of all, it is an insult and an anti-democratic practice to say that anti-European forces that challenge the European vision have prevailed in Britain. The Brexit vote translates into a condemnation of the Union, as it has become today. There is talk of mutual tolerance, public participation and respect, when promoting a Union in which everyone must agree to wrong policies and where any objections are condemned or eliminated, without the possibility of developing their arguments. You focus on European integration, while at the same time accusing nationalist movements as totalitarian. The promotion of Europe's cultural heritage and the participation of migrants are promoted when migrants are not openly accepting of the European mentality and culture. How can they participate in a program for European citizens when they are not Europeans themselves? I urge all those who speak of Euroscepticism to change their practices and approaches, because they are the ones who alienate the citizens of the states from the European edifice.

name: Sabine VERHEYEN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The “Europe for Citizens” program is an important program for today, when the call for more democracy and participation on the one hand and populist, nationalist and anti-European movements on the other hand are gaining more and more influence cohesion in the EU. It promotes historical awareness, civic engagement and helps to break down barriers and promote encounters and friendship between people in Europe. Today more than ever, we need a Europe that brings people together, not one that is built only from stones and legal books. The program already received a great positive response in the previous funding period, but has always been underfunded as the number of project applications is significantly higher than the number of approved projects. This situation has become even more precarious as a result of the drastic budget cuts by the member states in the current funding period, and many good projects that fully comply with the program guidelines have to be rejected year after year, which of course increases the frustration of the applicants significantly, because many are making a lot of effort to get good projects off the ground, and then in the end we cannot count on support. The program that can best help to increase understanding of Europe, the European values ​​and the structures of the EU, is by no means adequately funded. That is why the Committee on Culture and Parliament have repeatedly called for a budget increase from the current meager EUR 185 million to around EUR 500 million in the next medium-term financial framework, which would be just one euro per citizen. Along with many other suggestions in the report, this would be one of the first important steps to significantly increase the effectiveness of the program, because in contrast to many other initiatives and programs There is no shortage of good projects at EU level.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Yesterday, President Juncker presented a "White Paper on the Future of the EU", but there will be no new start for the 27 without the involvement of Europeans. There will be no strong European Union without citizens believing in the effectiveness of this project. Therefore, our goal should be an active Union, a Union promoting the inclusion of citizens, a Union bringing citizens closer to the Union institutions, but also a Union that can counter the growing wave of populism and Euroscepticism. These are the opportunities offered by the Europe for Citizens program. It is this program that promotes European citizenship, it is this program that promotes civic activity and, finally, it is this program that allows us to build a European identity, but in order for it to be able to meet the challenges facing us and the Union, it must be much more effective and equipped with more innovative methods. Of the recommendations that the author of this excellent report made, I will choose three important ones. First, a much more visible and reinforced communication strategy and promotion of this program. This means that the national contact points are active. Clerks cannot work there, creators and animators must work there. This program cannot appeal to the convinced. He also has to go to the circles that doubt in order to join us, to those who believe in the European project. The second issue, the "Europe for Citizens" program in its subject matter, must take into account the needs of citizens in its priorities, it must take into account the present and contemporary challenges. And finally, thirdly - it is indisputable, many of my speakers mentioned it - funding is (...). (The chairman cut off the speaker)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, according to the rhetoric of the Treaty on European Union, the Union is based on two basic principles: first, the principle of representative democracy, in which the Member States are represented in the Council and the peoples of the Member States are represented in the European Parliament. and, secondly, the principle of participatory democracy, which means that decisions are taken by the citizens themselves and this is done through referendums, as well as through the European legislative initiative. However, experience to date has shown that the European Union is afraid of referendums, since with them the people condemn its neoliberal policies, they condemn the European Union of bureaucracy and banking. The European Union has also shown that it does not want to facilitate the exercise of legislative initiative by citizens, as seen with "Save the Water". The alienation of citizens from the European Union is increasing because the Union's economic policy is based on the austerity and violent fiscal adjustment that have filled the Union with armies of the unemployed, the poor. Therefore, such superficial actions as this program can not cure the crisis of legitimacy that the Union is facing, especially when it comes to paternalistic programs, which are imposed from above by the elites. After all, this is demonstrated by the title of the program which is "Europe for Citizens" and not "Citizens' Europe".

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, we are celebrating 10 years of "Europe for Citizens", a program that has its origins in the 90s and earlier, when the Council of Europe had similar programs. I had the opportunity to participate in such programs, which were then called, for example, the Embassy of Local Democracy, today transformed into ALDA, and which is an integral part of this program for Europe for Citizens. So, these beginnings in which I participated, I must tell you at the beginning that they were great, that they significantly contributed to the development of democracy, that the presence of the Council of Europe then in Croatia, in the 90s, in Istria, in Brtonigla, in a small , a bilingual and multicultural municipality, was of paramount importance. That is why I think that the development of the projects we have today in the candidate countries is an excellent development of that program. I would also like to emphasize the twinning of cities, and that is a great program. We should also include the twinning of regions, because this is also a great exchange of experiences and the creation of a stronger European community. However, what I would like to emphasize here in particular is the thesis that this Report deals with, which I of course wholeheartedly support. However, I think we need to reverse the thesis, not to say that we are fighting against Euroscepticism, against populism, but we are fighting to have the truth about Europe. The truth about our past, which can be dodged behind these podiums here as well, and the truth about what lies ahead. Because if we want to tear Europe apart, as some want to tear it down, the European Union, we can do it. But someone will reassemble it in 30, 50 or I don’t know how many years. Therefore, I think the key point is to talk about the truth about Europe.

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, in recent years we have seen frustration and indifference on the part of European citizens towards the European Union and its structures, and indignation at neoliberal policies. The European Union, therefore, instead of radically changing its policies for the benefit of the people and the people, instead of realizing that its policies have created a Europe of many speeds, a Europe of the rich and the poor, a Europe without solidarity, pursues the same policies and at the same time funds programs aimed at embellishing this reality and distorting history, in order to cultivate the illusion of one-way streets. These are programs from above that want to implant in European citizens a common European identity, a common European conscience, a common view of history, without this being a conquest of the citizens. These are manipulative tools that will not stop European citizens, European youth, from fighting austerity for a better future and a better Europe.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, let me start with some common ground. Clearly, if your project for European integration is to recover – mercifully, without the United Kingdom – it will require an enhanced level of social solidarity between the peoples of Europe. So it is not surprising that integrationists should set such store by top—down projects designed to tell the citizens of Europe’s nation states that their prime collective identity should be a continental one rather than a national one. When, for example, German citizens are next told that Greek citizens need another euro bailout, federalists will wish their first reaction to be, ‘Yes, we Europeans must stand together’ and not ‘Why should more German money go to Greece?’ But I am afraid that you might as well push water uphill as try to indoctrinate people about the collective loyalties that they feel. In no other continent on earth are so many distinct cultures, countries and languages held in such close proximity. That is what makes Europe the most interesting continent. People like Mr Verhofstadt think Europe is a continent of dwarves that cannot compete in the modern world and that we need to bring every aspect of public policy under the EU umbrella. But there is a better way forward and that is to be less doctrinaire and less rigid, to get behind NATO as our key defensive alliance, to allow nation states to return to national currencies that reflect their economic conditions, to trust that the peoples of a democratic Europe will be too sensible to return to the days of ultra-nationalism that caused the shedding of so much blood. But to try and force a European identity through top—down programmes such as Europe for Citizens is self—defeating. You are wasting your time and you are also wasting our money.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: - Mr. President, Austrian economist Ludwig von Mises has said that at the basis of all totalitarian doctrines is the belief that rulers are wiser and higher in spirit than their subjects. Who better than one of your liberal-libertarian thinkers to describe you? This text is, in fact, a jewel of totalitarian propaganda and a real attack on freedom and democracy. Any criticism against your Euro-federalist project must be eradicated. You even want to use EU taxpayers' money to fight the stigmatization of immigrants and develop counter-narratives. However, it seems to me that the peoples of Europe have sent a clear message on the subject, whether in the Hungarian referendum or in the various opinion polls carried out. In France, 56% of those questioned in 2015 were opposed to welcoming migrants. As at the end of Tartuffe, your false devotion to freedom and democracy is unmasked and this report, one more reason for the peoples of Europe to stand up.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Mr President, Europe is undergoing challenging times. In the current political season, with elections to be held in various EU countries, the growing Eurosceptic sentiments are creating deep divisions and social polarisation, threatening the very foundations and the very existence of the European project. The European Union needs to reconnect with its citizens, putting them back at the heart of its agenda. Encouraging civic participation and enhancing people’s understanding of the history and diversity of the Union has never been as important for the future of Europe as it is today. This is the litmus test that Europe cannot fail. That is why I support this report and its very symbolic – and the first of its kind – programme, Europe for Citizens, which aims to bring the European Union closer to its citizens. The programme has reached more than seven million citizens in thousands of towns and cities around Europe, helping them to better understand the European Union, promoting the Union’s ideals and values, and improving the conditions for direct civic and democratic participation and active dialogue between the EU and its citizens. The programme provides a unique opportunity to strengthen a sense of European citizenship and belonging, and enhances solidarity and mutual understanding. Active citizenship, education and intercultural dialogue are paramount to the building of an open and inclusive society. This programme is one of the key instruments to achieve this. Despite its success, we need constantly to reinforce the programme and increase its budget, projects and goals. Member States also need to get actively involved and support the programme, further raising its profile by making people more aware of it. It is important that the programme focuses not only on the past, but also on the future and on current challenges such as migration, radicalisation and social inclusion, among others. I hope that the Commission and the Member States will implement the recommendations of this report, which will help to reinforce the programme.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, cad a chiallaíonn an téarma Saoránacht Eorpach? Is téarma leathan atá ann gur féidir míniú éagsúil a fháil amach as. Tá sé tábhachtach ar ndóigh go mbeidh rud éigin mar seo againn agus sinn ag maireachtaint in am atá an-neamhchinnte. Ach mar fheisirí, caithfimid freagracht réadúil a ghlacadh agus aitheantas a thabhairt do na dúshláin atá ag an Aontas Eorpach. Caithfear an cheist a chur cén chúis leis an athrú seo? Tá treoir nua ag teastáil uainn, treoir ina bhfuil ceannasaíocht chróga agus chinnte, a thugann cothromaíocht dár ndaoine. Tá an eite-dheis ag méadú agus táimse den tuairim nach é níos mór cónaidhmeachta an freagra. Ní níos mó ná níos lú Eoraip an freagra ach is Eoraip shóisialta an freagra. Eoraip nach bhfuil ag dul i dtreo fórsaí míleata ach i dtreo na síochána, i dtreo na fostaíochta agus infheistíocht phoiblí. Eoraip a chosnaíonn a muintir ón mbochtanas agus a chuireann fáilte rompusan nach bhfuil sábháilte ina thír dhúchais. Eoraip a chuireann cearta daoine mar phríomhfheidhm. Sin é dar liomsa an sainmhíniú ar an dtéarma Saoránacht Eorpach.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the rapporteur for her excellent report, which highlights the encouraging results achieved by the "Europe for Citizens" program, including the geographical rebalancing of projects and above all the participation of citizens. Precisely for this reason, although starting from the positive note, I am speaking to underline a persistent discrepancy between the concerns that the European Union and the Member States declare they have about growing populism and anti-Europeanism and the choices made so far. The "Europe for Citizens" program, which is so valuable that it is described as "unique in promoting civic engagement among European citizens", continues to receive insufficient funding to allow it to be properly implemented. Therefore, I fully agree with the recommendations made, in particular: a more participatory legal basis for the program and a more adequate financial envelope. On the political level, the financial endowment is a yardstick that quantifies the level of importance actually recognized to the program.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - The Europe for Citizens program is unique in that it really gives citizens the opportunity to become personally involved in learning about the history and present of the EU and its Member States in various fields. I have a very good personal experience when a small town in eastern Slovakia, Medzev, as a member of the Charter of European Rural Communities applied for a grant and hosted 270 guests from every corner of Europe for five days under the Europe for Citizens program. Meeting Dan, a Swede, a Portuguese or a Slovenian in a small space at the same time was grateful for the locals to exchange experiences, learn about cultural and sports traditions, but above all it was an opportunity for friendships that lasted for years. The technical theme of the conference "How EU enlargement in 2004 affected citizens in small rural communities in Europe" also contributed to gaining further knowledge not only for the participants, the hosts, but I also received strong messages personally as an MEP and other guests present. I believe that we will also give the Europe for Citizens a green light in the future by increasing the budget.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, it is typical of the Europe for Citizens program being criticized by the National Front and other extremist parties. Populists and extremists need people to forget history so that history can repeat itself. The "Europe for Citizens" program is intended to help civil society actions, municipalities, as my colleague Smolková recalled here, so that they can exchange each other, get to know each other better, think about the history and the future of a common Europe. The only disadvantage of this program is its underfunding. Indeed, one hundred and eighty-five million euros for six years, this is only a symbolic amount for such an important program. I must evaluate positively the management of this program, the contact points and also the simplification of its operation. Europe stands for the support of citizens, the European Union does not have a perspective without the understanding and support of the citizens themselves. If we do not want to repeat the devastating history of wars, we must support civil ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, Europe is the sum total of its citizens and that includes the millions of British citizens living, working and travelling within and beyond the European Union, particularly young people broadening their minds, encountering the other, learning life skills. In fact, learning how to be good, responsible citizens in the 21st century, both at home and abroad.  The young people who could vote in last year’s British referendum overwhelmingly voted to remain in the EU. However, Teresa May’s continued direction towards a hard and damaging Brexit threatens to rob future generations of many wonderful, life-enhancing, character building and community minded opportunities that benefit not just themselves but the places in which they live.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I see that democratic engagement and civic participation are encouraged under this programme. Wonderful! A brilliant idea, but the problem is that this institution does not really believe in it, because if this institution gave a damn about democratic engagement then when the Irish people voted against the Lisbon Treaty, because they did not want to give up any more sovereignty, you would have respected that. When the people of Ireland voted against Nice you did not accept it. You sent the bully-boys over. You sent the Commissioners over with Michael O’Leary on Ryanair planes to convince us we were wrong. Where is the connection there with democratic engagement? We engaged, you rejected! When it comes to Greece, you rejected ‘Oxi’. If you want to do something about scepticism, then kill the causes of scepticism. Appreciate democracy. Shut up talking about it and do it!

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Mr Chairman! The aim of this program is to contribute to the understanding of its history and diversity by the citizens of the Union, as well as to build a civil society and to improve the conditions for civic and democratic activity. This is especially important in times of European Euroscepticism. The simplification of the structure of the program and its greater accessibility for applicants as well as the improvement of the application submission thanks to the digital e-form deserve a positive assessment. The downside is the reduction of the program budget compared to the previous edition. This program allows for a creative exchange of experiences, building bonds between EU citizens and promoting European values ​​and, perhaps most importantly, preserving the memory of our history. We note that every year more and more valuable applications are submitted with a high substantive level and a wide range of impact at the level of many European Union countries, but unfortunately too small percentage of these projects have a chance to be implemented due to the low budget of this program.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Europe for Citizens is a program with an excellent title, but it needs to be well explained and managed and, above all, funded in order to have concrete effects. I congratulate the rapporteur and I obviously support the report. In the current context of growing Euroscepticism, bringing the European Union closer to its citizens must be a priority for all of us. There is a need for an improvement of the program, there is a need for funding taking into account the geographical criteria. I am glad that the two components of the program, European memory and democratic engagement and civic participation, have become multinational and will apply by 2020. I support the rapporteur's concern that the European Parliament be a co-legislator, in the end this institution represents citizens - over five hundreds of millions of people, and we are directly elected to represent them. And I believe that all democratic institutions, national and European, must not forget that Europe for Citizens is in fact a program that shows that citizens are the most important, and that our work must have beneficial effects on citizens.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, firstly I welcome the fact that Commissioner King is wearing a green tie. It may be indicative of his desire to become an Irish citizen like some of his British colleagues have done here in the Parliament. If so, you are most welcome, Commissioner. A propos the debate ‘Europe for Citizens’ the question is: are the citizens for Europe? Not so, or not enough of them, and people have indicated reasons – populism, scepticism, nationalism, self-serving opportunism à la Marine Le Pen, and so forth. The rapporteur mentioned one or two other reasons today which are very important. One: the programme we are talking about is not well enough known, and if people are not aware of something they cannot appreciate it. That is the first challenge. The second is the low success rate in applications. Instead of people being delighted to apply and be successful, they get deflated. We have to make sure that does not happen in the future. I agree completely that we need a bigger budget, and we should also expand the programme into the voluntary sector and the sporting sector, where there is a true dimension of European value.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for the debate this morning and for the report. Thank you for the various comments, which I shall make sure are reported in full and shared with my colleague, Commissioner Avramopoulos. If I may, I would like to thank Mr Kelly. I have a very warm memory of the five years I spent, in one way or another, on the island of Ireland. We have got this report looking at the three years of the programme. We need now to learn the lessons from that experience for the next generation of citizenship programmes. Let me take this opportunity to stress again the importance of this work, to reconnect with our citizens and engage with civil society, in particular – as a number of people have said – with young people, to build an understanding of our history, to celebrate our diversity, and to counter intolerance, not least at a time when, here and there, we see the rise of polarisation. Today’s debate is an important contribution to what is going to be our joint reflection on how best to take this work forward. Let us use the Europe for Citizens programme to establish a public forum for this important debate about our shared future. Let us work together to reinforce the programme as an instrument which can reach out and engage citizens across Europe.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: speaker. -  Mr. president; Thank you, colleagues, for your kind interventions; Thank you, Commissioner King, for his position on the proposed legislation we are asking for. I recognize that talking about European citizenship in these difficult times is a real challenge but, despite certain Eurosceptic views that we have heard, it is realistic and necessary. European citizenship is at the root of the idea of ​​a genuine European Union and in it also rests the hope for its future. Today this project is progressing with difficulty, despite the fact that it is part of the set of values ​​that inspired the development of the Union towards something more than an economic club. Within the complex historical and political moment that we are living, I consider that this report on the implementation of the Europe for Citizens program is of crucial importance, because we want integrative programs that favor an analysis of our common past, overcoming separating historical accounts and grievances. I want to see in this initiative the political expression that we do not resign ourselves to accepting a future of skepticism, selfishness and disunity among Europeans. This program is a strong and forceful call for European integration and solidarity. For all this, thank you very much, kind colleagues.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - 2014-2020 The Europe for Citizens program aims to strengthen the links between the European Union and its citizens, to contribute to citizens' understanding of the European Union, its history and its diversity, to to promote European citizenship and to improve the conditions for civic and democratic participation at European Union level. This report presents the first experiences of a program that has been running for two years, analyzes what is working at this stage of the Europe for Citizens program and what are the main issues of concern for applicants and beneficiaries. The main concern is the programme's budget for 2014-2020, which has been reduced by 14% compared to the previous program. The European Parliament therefore considers it extremely important to increase the programme's budget due to the high level of interest in the program and the small number of projects selected for funding.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The report on the implementation of the "Europe for Citizens" program for the period 2014-2020 attempts to analyze the results of a program with a special symbolic charge. The development of a closer relationship between the European Union and European citizens has been a declared goal of all stakeholders as well as European policy makers. But due importance was never given in practice. Especially in recent years, the effects of the political and economic crisis affecting Europe as a whole have intensified the sense of alienation of citizens and the current of Euroscepticism and the questioning of a united Europe. We are therefore called upon to promote change for a more social Europe, so that efforts to inform citizens about the common values, the purpose of the Union and, above all, public participation have a real background. Even the information becomes more difficult, when the project budget is reduced by 14% compared to the previous program for the period 2007-2013. In any case, after all, the real issue is not the wrapper, but the essential content. We need another Europe, with more solidarity both between the Member States and within European societies, with redistribution from the rich to the poor and not the other way around, as is largely the case today.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Dear fellow Members! I believe that the Europe for Citizens program is indeed an excellent opportunity to forge a closer bond and a closer relationship between European citizens and the Union, and this program will go a long way towards promoting a truly united Europe. However, I think that, as this is the only program that focuses on European citizens and approaches the subject of the program from its aspects, more energy and work needs to be invested. In agreement with the rapporteur, I also suggest something as a solution to boost the program, that an increase in the budget is essential, and that the program gain the same interest among the target groups as in previous years. I suggest that we increase the visibility of the program by giving the national contact points greater, stronger communication with the citizens of the Member States. Thank you for listening!

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. – I highly welcome any initiative that aims at bringing the European Union closer to its citizens, therefore I strongly support the Europe for Citizens programme. The results of this have shown that there is a need for such initiatives during the time of crisis. However, the insufficient budget caused relatively a low level of success of individual projects. Moreover, quite often, the lack of qualifications of applicants resulted in a lower approval rate for accepted projects. Therefore, I would suggest further development of a system of training courses and workshops on drafting projects among potential applicants. Furthermore, the list of possible partners in all Member States would facilitate the formation of certain collaborations among units willing to enter the Europe for Citizens programme. I do not agree, however, with the selection of Article 352 TFEU as the sole legal base for the proposal, limiting the role of Parliament in the legislation process. I call for reconsidering the base for the next period of the programme. The involvement of Parliament on an equal level with the Council shall be re-established.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing.- I welcome the report, especially as it covers people with disabilities in several places.I fully agree that additional needs should always be taken into account, including the costs of sign language interpreters for the deaf or the costs of an accompanying person for the visually impaired or people with reduced mobility.I also support the inclusion of accessibility aspects in all cases in the proposed user-friendly communication portal (the all-in-one online platform).We must set a good example!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – The report has evaluated the implementation of the ‘Europe for Citizens’ programme 2014-2020, presenting an overview of the current state of play in the implementation of the programme and the main areas of concern for applicants and beneficiaries. The report shows the great interest raised by the programme and the low rate of success of the projects, proposing therefore an increase in the budget. The report comes up with several proposals to improve the programme: sharing best practices between Members States and beneficiaries in an active network; changing the parameter in the calculation of the lump sum for travel costs to take into account the geographical differences and cost of living in the participating countries; training courses and workshops on the topic of identifying international partners; improving the method for providing feedback to rejected applicants in the current programme by involving the network more.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - This program is based on unacceptable assumptions and from which we distance ourselves absolutely. On the one hand, the bleaching of EU history and policies, artificially imposing a European identity, which does not exist. The aim is to create a feeling that, in a moment of deep crisis in and of the EU, is very far from the legitimate and just distancing of the peoples from the European integration project. On the other hand, we reaffirm the objectives of falsifying historical reality, bleaching Nazi-fascism and its class nature, equating fascism and communism, legitimizing the criminalization and illegalization of communist movements. It is omitted that anti-fascism was and is in the essence of the liberating action and struggle of the communists, for which millions gave their lives, or the struggle for democracy, as in Portugal the PCP and the Portuguese communists did. It deliberately seeks to hide the incomparable contribution of the Soviet revolution and other experiences in building a socialist society, to social progress and advances in all areas of life, all over the world. The call for a higher level of execution of the “European memory” subprogram and the celebrations that until 2020 will be eligible for funding, speak well of the reckoning with history and the anti-communism that guide this program.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The Europe for Citizens program is one of the key tools for strengthening European identity, supporting a culture based on solidarity, tolerance and respect, and for a better understanding of the values ​​underlying the European project. In the context of growing Euroscepticism, especially with the support of a new wave of populism both in Europe and abroad, Europe for Citizens is becoming all the more important as we need to remind citizens of the benefits of EU membership. . The correct implementation of this program must focus on building bridges between the European institutions and civil society, in order to be constantly aware of what Europeans think about the real problems they face, from immigration to social inclusion. That being said, it is disappointing that, despite these arguments and the sensitive context in which we find ourselves, the budget for this program has been significantly cut in the current financial year. However, the S&D Group understands that a strong Europe means not only economic growth, but also solidarity between citizens, and calls for an allocation of 500 million for the next MFF, which would mean only 1 euro per citizen.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - The aim of the report is to provide an initial experience of the implementation of the Europe for Citizens Program 2014-2020. This program is described as a unique European platform that guarantees the promotion of Union citizens' participation in public life, either directly or through targeted organizations. The main concern is undoubtedly the programme's budget, which has been reduced by 14% compared to the previous period. The reduction in the financial envelope will undoubtedly have a major impact on the functioning of the Europe for Citizens program as a whole. Due to the high level of interest in the program, it is extremely important to explain the objectives and ensure sufficient funding. In many Member States, potential applicants have difficulties with project proposals because they lack capacity in the field of transnational partnerships or the European dimension of their project is not sufficiently clear. In this context, the capacity of stakeholders could be considered. The European Parliament, as the only directly elected EU institution representing almost 500 million citizens, and one of the EU's legislators, has a role to play in adopting a program specifically designed to promote citizens' participation and raise their awareness of the EU's history and values. Because this is in the interest of the Community as a whole.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. - In the last decade, Europe and the world have made leaps in the development of information technology and Internet communication tools. I am convinced that the use of these modern measures in public administration is therefore inevitable, and we should also strive to make the political decision-making process transparent and as close to EU citizens as possible. The potential of modern information and communication technologies would be particularly useful in building e-administration, thanks to which citizens would get official information first-hand and could also settle many life matters without leaving home. Equally important, from the point of view of public administration, would be the function that would allow citizens to consult strategies on important public issues and increase their active participation in the election process. Undoubtedly, the potential of modern technologies and methods of communication should be used in public life as widely as possible. However, one should also remember about the risks that arise from the limitations of access to new technologies still existing in many areas of Europe and the quite frequent phenomenon of the lack of Internet skills, occurring most often among citizens of the 50+ generation.

name: Emma McCLARKIN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the scale of recent trade flows in illegal wildlife and wildlife products is unprecedented, with recent data showing a sharp decline in the number of some species, many of them facing extinction. This presents a serious threat to our environment and may have a permanent consequence on our biodiversity. We must also concern ourselves with the impact illegal wildlife trade has on the global economy, good governance and the wider connections with other criminal activities. It was with these considerations in mind that I proposed to the Committee on International Trade (INTA) to draft an own-initiative report on the EU common commercial policy in the context of wildlife sustainability, because trade policy can, and should, address wildlife conservation, support sustainable development and environmental protection. My report looks at the challenges we face and gives practical solutions on effective use of the resources available, with better implementation of our current policies giving tangible and comprehensive recommendations to the Commission on how trade and environmental policies can work together to tackle illegal wildlife trade inside the EU and globally. However, the report strongly recommends that we do not overburden the existing framework with the creation of new rules and mechanisms. Instead, the priority should be the implementation of the present framework in the context of the global trade and environmental regimes, such as the WTO, CITES, the WCO, the UNDP and the OECD. We must also seek further and deeper cooperation with the private sector and non-governmental organisations, ensuring that all stakeholders involved have a say and contribute to the fight against illegal wildlife trade. Initiatives such as the United for Wildlife Transport Taskforce should be widely promoted, as they draw upon the linkages between e-commerce, transportation and distribution to establish well-rounded and integrated approaches addressing both supply and demand, as well as focusing on breaking chains to tackle illegal trade in wildlife and wildlife products. Sharing data and knowledge is imperative and this report stresses that there is still work to do at this level, both within the EU and with partner countries. Customs procedures must be assessed, and emphasis and resources should be put on strengthening compliance and law enforcement at national and regional levels. The EU must step up its efforts in the provision of training, information and capacity building, full customs in developing countries, and promote transparency and good governance. To tackle illegal wildlife crime we must also tackle its enablers. Corruption is one of the main facilitators of this activity. This report strongly encourages the EU and Member States to increase their vigilance, to reinforce cross-border measures to identify and prevent money-laundering associated with wildlife trafficking. My report supports the inclusion of anti-corruption provisions in future trade agreements. And as part of the EU’s ongoing commitment to sustainable development, our trade policy must strive for solid and detailed sustainable development chapters in its future trade agreements, similar to the one included in the EU-Vietnam FTA. It is imperative that we lead on the negotiation and implementation of higher standards covering trade in wildlife in the EU and globally. Trade policy is an important tool at our disposal and we must make the best use of it to fight this crime, and to protect and promote wildlife and our natural resources. If we do nothing, they will be extinct. Finally, I would like to thank my adviser Alex Boyd for his advice and support, and colleagues in INTA for their support and hard work on this file, proving that we are all committed to the fight against illegal wildlife crime and that we want to keep this fight a priority so that future generations to come will enjoy the magnificence of our precious wildlife.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I want to strongly support this report, and I am very pleased that, as part of the European Union's agenda, we are not only discussing the protection of human rights anywhere in the world, but also addressing the protection of wildlife rights. This is really a very important topic, and I am very glad that part of our trade policy is to protect plants and animals more. In the Czech Republic, I deal with so-called dog breeding, which is the illegal breeding of pets, dogs and cats, and I deal with the smuggling and export of these animals to other countries of the European Union. I must state that, according to some reports, the so-called zoo business, the zoo mafia, is the third most lucrative type of organized crime, alongside prostitution and the smuggling of narcotics and drugs. So this is a very serious problem, the smuggling of species and plants in general, and it is good that the European Union is dealing with this. In addition to this material, however, we should also address the issue of dog breeding and the problems of pets that are freely smuggled without clear rules across the countries of the European Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, illegal wildlife trafficking has in fact become one of the most profitable criminal activities in the world, with an estimated total value of between EUR 8 and 20 billion per year. Union action must first focus on the problem of corruption, which is one of the main drivers of the illicit wildlife trade. Current and future negotiations on trade agreements must consider all possible measures related to both legal and illegal wildlife trade, starting with the introduction of anti-corruption provisions in future free trade agreements. It is also necessary to ensure that sufficient funds are earmarked for capacity building measures. The Union must aim to offer training support in producer countries not only for customs and crime-fighting authorities, but also for producer associations, cooperatives and social enterprises, which allow local communities to take advantage of legal sustainable trade.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the revenue from the illegal wildlife trade is estimated at around EUR 20 billion, making it the fourth most lucrative criminal activity in the world. As the illegal trade in wildlife destroys ecosystems and poses a threat to global biodiversity, the European Union adopted in February 2016 an action plan to combat the illegal trade in wildlife within the Union and to strengthen the of the European Union in the global campaign to combat these illegal activities. The Union action plan to tackle trafficking in wildlife must help prevent illicit trafficking, reduce the supply and demand of illegal species, and strengthen the implementation of existing rules for the fight against organized crime.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: – Mr President, my thanks go to Emma McClarkin for her well-reasoned and clear report with recommendations to protect wildlife in current and future EU trade agreements. My thanks to the Commission for the proposals to ban, in the EU, raw ivory exports. Tomorrow is World Wildlife Day, so let’s celebrate this year’s progress in protecting wildlife against trafficking: China’s full ban and the near ban in the USA, stricter rules in France on hunting trophies and the burning of ivory by the Kenyan Government. However, this is just tackling illegal trade. The McClarkin report also tackles legal trade and, of course, we know the crossover is mostly complicated as plants, animals, birds, etc. move between the two: legal or illegal.  The Convention on the International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) COP recently delivered tough new rules and more protection for over 500 species, but more needs to be done. Member States, politicians and the public have the power to protect and reduce demand. This report is a good step along the road, so thank you Emma.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague Ms McClarkin so much for her report. My congratulations to her. I do, however, want to stress here that we will miss the Brits negotiating on the basis of the report that Ms McClarkin has just outlined. I do not really understand how the Brits will continue to try to convince trading partners on the sustainability issue, because we can only convince our partners if we have the weight of the whole European Union with its 500 million people. The smaller you are, the less chance you have to convince your partners about these goals we have in common, and that I am sure we will have in common in the future also.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: - Mr President, it seems very worrying that illegal trafficking in wild species continues to increase and I want to stress here that it also affects the aquatic domain: red corals, sturgeon eggs and eel fry are trafficked within Europe and outside Europe . We assign recommendations to third countries, trying to reverse the harmful processes known as IUU fisheries. However, it seems to me fundamental to set an example inside doors and prevent illegal trafficking, which, in the cases mentioned, are IUU fishing. I am pleased, as mentioned in the report, for the efforts made by the European Union with the World Trade Organization to prevent subsidies on fishing that are harmful, which can jeopardize the sustainable management of fisheries and threaten the conservation of sensitive species. As we said in the Committee on Fisheries, I think it is important to recognize the champions in the fight against trafficking in wild species, giving them a European level recognition.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for this morning’s presentation, and the debate and comments that have been made on a subject which, I must say, is actually very close to my heart. In particular, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Emma McClarkin, for her excellent report. As has been pointed out, the scale of illegal wildlife trade and the impact on populations of vulnerable plant and animal species are extremely serious. Concerted international action is needed to prevent the loss of such species due to greed and ill-informed behaviour.  We are focusing today on trade-related aspects of this fight. At the same time, we should recall the importance of EU action in other policy areas as well, such as the provision of support to developing countries through our cooperation work. The report refers to the Trade for All communication, which underlines the importance of a values-based trade policy. I welcome the high degree of consensus that I understand exists between the political groups on the need for action to tackle this appalling phenomenon of illegal wildlife trade, an area of economic activity that is clearly contrary to our values.  The key multilateral instrument to address wildlife trade is, as we all know, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). CITES decisions apply to all CITES parties and, furthermore, it has the ability to take action if a party fails to follow the rules. Support for the effective implementation of CITES is a key feature of our trade policy. It is one of the international conventions that must be implemented effectively by beneficiaries of trade preferences under the EU’s GSP+ scheme. Commitments on effective implementation of CITES are included in the trade and sustainable development chapters of EU free trade agreements and the Commission does not hesitate to raise CITES issues directly in our dialogues with trade partners as necessary.  Today’s report also correctly identifies an important role for the private sector in tackling wildlife trafficking, including businesses in the aviation and shipping sectors. The concept of responsible business conduct is one that is strongly supported by the EU and is increasingly reflected in our various trade agreements. A high—value illegal trade such as that of illegal wildlife creates the conditions for corruption, as has been noted. As announced in the Trade for All communication and referred to in today’s report, the Commission intends to include provisions to address corruption linked to international trade in future trade agreements. The EU also successfully proposed, at the last Conference of the Parties to CITES, a resolution which explicitly calls for dedicated action against corruption linked to wildlife trafficking. I can assure you that the report will be considered very carefully by the Commission, including in the ongoing work on the implementation of the EU Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking, and today’s timely debate has again highlighted this critical issue at the intersection of environmental and trade policy. As many of you have said, it is imperative that we take action to tackle the scourge of this trade. So thank you to the rapporteur and thank you to those who participated in this morning’s discussion.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - It is imperative to fight against the trafficking of certain wild species from which criminal and mafia networks take advantage: as the rapporteur underlined, the illegal trade in wild fauna and flora is the fourth most lucrative criminal activity, with a turnover of up to 20 billion euros. These profits are also often used to finance terrorist activities to which Europe is particularly vulnerable. Beyond our environmental awareness, it is therefore indeed a safety issue! We should also note that we have a duty to look beyond the imperatives of the market since this subject is also part of a perspective of sustainable co-development of the countries from which these species come, often from the African continent. However, certain communities on the ground are very often dependent, socially and economically, on the sustainable trade of these species, and this is why it is essential to support them in order to achieve a trade that is mindful of biodiversity and that leads to the preservation employment and growth of the communities concerned. There is no need to put in place yet another legislation: let's apply the already existing standards in this area!

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- The constant increase in illegal trade in wild flora and fauna endangers biodiversity, destroys the ecosystem, and increases the number of animals and plants that become extinct or endangered.The wealth of fauna and flora is an integral part of humanity and our planet, and therefore should not be underestimated, but concrete measures are needed that will enable their preservation and smart management.Unfortunately, the European Union is a large market for illegal wildlife products, but also an important transit hub.Therefore, joint efforts are needed to prevent such actions, and in this context it is extremely important to involve the private sector, non-governmental organizations, but also social networks.I am sure that economic development and the use of natural resources are two things that can and must go together!

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thirty seconds: I would like to ask you and through you to President Tajani to publicly express your personal and institutional condemnation of the statements made yesterday by Mr Korwin-Mikke.We cannot allow certain shameful statements against fundamental principles such as gender equality on which the European Union is founded to be tolerated by the House of Europeans.Certain statements cannot go unpunished and therefore we ask President Tajani to take action.On behalf of the European socialists, I would like to express my strongest condemnation and reiterate our support for the equality of men and women and against all gender discrimination.For our part, mind you, we will never take a step backwards in the wake of the defense of rights and equality.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr Pittella, thank you for what you have said.I will convey them, as President-in-Office, to the President of Parliament, Mr Tajani.Mr Korwin Mikke has the floor.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, I move to postpone the waiver of immunity of Ms Marine Le Pen until after the presidential elections. Unfortunately, if we vote for this she will get an additional 100 000 votes. She will post herself as persecuted by bureaucracy and she will win the election because of this. If she is in prison she will win the election for sure! I move to postpone. We are interfering in the electoral process in France.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr Korwin Mikke, I suppose you would have something to say about what Mr Pittella said.You were original.I would like to say that, as far as your request is concerned, pursuant to Rule 180 τήσεις 1 of the Rules of Procedure, requests for the waiver of the immunity of any MEP are made by show of hands - not by roll-call vote.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, under Rule 181a and Rule 49 in relation to the Committee on Legal Affairs, I would like to raise the very urgent case of Alexander Adamescu, a German citizen living in London, who is subject to a political European arrest warrant issued by the Romanian Government and the Romanian police. Mr Adamescu’s father had already been arrested on the same charge and he died in prison. His wife has had an attempt to remove her illegally from the United Kingdom by gangsters, and what we have to face is the European arrest warrant being used here by a country as a member of the European Union, for political purposes. I urge you to raise this at the highest level with the President and the committee under these rules.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Thank you, Mr Woolfe.Before we go to the polls, I am pleased to greet Mr Habib El Malki, Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Kingdom of Morocco, and his accompanying delegation, who are in the gallery.Mr Habib El Malki and his delegation are paying a working visit to the European Parliament and honoring us with their presence in today's vote.I warmly welcome them.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: We proceed to the voting.The first issue is the report of Laura Ferrara, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the application for the waiver of the immunity of Marine Le Pen (2016/2295 (IMM)) (A8-0047 / 2017).A proposal has been tabled by Mr Korwin Mikke to postpone the vote.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr President, could we have a block vote for all the amendments by the Marine Le Pen group?

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Mister President!With all the appreciation of your management today, you have obviously committed two fundamental violations of the principle of equality.On point one: You don't even see how the vote is.Secondly, you ignore when someone happens to say “point of order”, then you are obviously above things and ignore that. I would ask you to change your presidency, which is otherwise very much appreciated, and to be democratic and fair.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Thank you very much, Mr Obermayr, for your appreciation of the chairman and his staff.I want to assure you that all the voting by show of hands had a very clear result.The amendments of the political group were rejected by an overwhelming majority and this was evident in the votes you requested to be taken by roll call vote.They were rejected by the same overwhelming majority.Mrs Costa has the floor.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, just to say that today is an important day because Parliament has expressed its will to support more culture, which Europe so much needs, as a production of values, as a cultural integration, but alsoas a great force of innovation, of youth work, above all.I would like to say that in the excitement of the moment, my car didn't work and it didn't register my vote in favor, of course.I mean, when I pressed it didn't ring, some particular situation must have happened, so I would like you to register my vote in favor.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mrs Costa, your clarification will be taken into account.As my colleagues have informed me of Mr Preda's proposal, we can vote on en bloc amendments only when their content is relevant and compatible.I can therefore not accept Mr Preda's proposal.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Voting time is over.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - From now on, the Commission will evaluate energy agreements concluded by Member States with third countries for oil and gas, but electricity agreements will also be evaluated after signing, a system that is completely inefficient because it is very difficult to break an agreement after-you have signed or in full political or economic conflict.Third countries with abusive or expansionary policies must not be a source of energy for the Union.An energy-independent European Union can make firm decisions and spare the sensibilities of leaders who believe that there is a currency for all.Human rights are not negotiable - Member States should think about this when signing energy or any other type of agreement with third countries.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! I voted in favor of the Commission's proposal to amend the information exchange mechanism for intergovernmental agreements with third countries in the field of energy. I believe that this proposal can improve the functioning of the European Union market and increase its influence on the shape of agreements concluded by Member States with third countries. The existing regulations did not work in practice because they were based on the ex-post evaluation mechanism, according to which states were obliged to submit contracts to the Commission only after signing them. As a consequence, in the event of a negative assessment, it was difficult or even impossible to withdraw or change them, as potentially such actions could cause political and economic crises between the EU Member State and the third country. The ex ante evaluation system will allow not only to avoid these problems, but also give the Commission a real influence on the shape of concluded contracts. Changing the mechanism will help to increase legal certainty as the signed contracts will be in advance (...). (The chairman cut off the speaker)

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the establishment of a mechanism for the exchange of information on intergovernmental agreements and non-binding instruments between Member States and third countries in the energy sector could be a step forward to ensure legal transparency on past agreements. and future.
