This instrument should facilitate and promote forms of coordination between producer countries, transit countries, consumer countries, but it could also make it possible to take giant steps in involving the populations affected by the effects of these agreements, in particular as regards the construction of infrastructures impacting also from an environmental point of view such as the case of gas pipelines, oil pipelines and regasifiers. In fact, the information exchange mechanism should also be based on the legal significance of the correct application of the Aarhus Convention on access to information, public participation in decision-making processes and access to justice in environmental matters, the purpose of which is to guarantee citizens have the right to transparency, to participation in the matter, to the decision-making processes of local, national and cross-border government, concerning the environment and therefore also the infrastructures already mentioned, in essence, legal assessments are welcome, without neglecting any aspect . For this I voted positively.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, I voted against the Krasnodębski report because it essentially initiates the usurpation of powers by the Member States and their transfer to the European Commission, in breach of the Treaty on European Union. The European Union is known to be based on the principle of donors of power, which means that the Member States of the Union have the presumption of competence, and the institutions of the Union have only those powers which are expressly conferred on them by the Treaties. Therefore, the joint exercise of sovereign powers by the Member States takes place only when explicitly provided for in the Treaties and can not be done through secondary Union law, as this upsets the institutional balance and distribution of powers between the Member States of the Union. This report proposes, in breach of the Treaty, the limitation of the sovereign powers of the Member States to conclude transnational energy contracts and gives the European Commission the right to evaluate and approve these transnational contracts in advance, in accordance with violation of the Treaty on European Union itself, thus giving the European Commission the right of veto.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this report, and I support all the reports in Parliament on the Energy Union.It is very important to me that a real energy union is created, so that our internal energy market is not so fragmented.I think we need to reap the full benefits of our large internal market, that is, to achieve the lowest possible prices, to achieve innovative energy management practices.Of course, this area also includes the obligation to introduce a higher degree of transparency into the negotiation of these intergovernmental agreements.I welcome this ex ante rule, I think it is necessary and will lead to better efficiency in the Commission's work in negotiating these intergovernmental agreements.The current rule was insufficient, as many years of practice have shown.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, today I voted in favor of ending discrimination against Bulgaria. It is time to end the humiliating treatment of my fellow citizens and the nearly 70 million other Europeans from whom the United States requires visas. The European Commission has chosen to violate its own law, even after a ruling by the Court of Justice of the European Union, instead of imposing visas on US citizens, putting Washington above the law. In this way, the European Commission is creating a "two-speed Europe", while at the same time claiming that it is fighting for equality. In view of this, yesterday I met with the Legal Service of the European Parliament, with which we discussed and outlined the next steps to combat this discrimination against Bulgaria. The message is clear. If the European Commission does not introduce visas for Americans within two months, we will sue the Court for this inaction. The law is one and applies to all.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!We have been creating the European Union for 60 years.In this process, we have come to a point where the free movement of people among the Member States is one of our fundamental achievements, but the Union also aims to maintain visa reciprocity with third countries.This should be a very important principle, because on the one hand it refers to the internal principle of solidarity between the Member States towards third countries, but also, in my opinion, it has - and should have - an integrative meaning within.I regret that we are not further implementing the agreement with the United States, I mean TTIP, because this process could also be used to ensure that the United States respects our position on visa reciprocity.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!There is one thing I would like to highlight in this vote.Of course, I support the principle of reciprocity, but I would like to draw your attention to the permanent inconsistency in this matter.We are dealing with a situation where, both on one side and on the other side of the ocean, the possible effects of failure to implement the principle of reciprocity in this matter for citizens are neglected.I believe that more consistency is needed here.On the one hand, successive presidents of the United States promise to abolish visas, and on the other hand, the institutions of the European Union are constantly fighting inconsistently for the citizens of these five countries.I draw attention to the need for greater consistency, greater determination, and I share these remarks concerning being careful in reacting to the current situation.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - Mr President, I understand what loyalty between Member States is, but everything has its limits.I think that the rights of two sovereign countries to organize the rules between citizens and visa requirements should remain in the hands of those sovereign states and should not be the subject of some kind of hostage-taking from the European level.We experienced a similar situation as the Czech Republic some time ago, when it came to the introduction of visas by Canada for our country.It has been made clear to us by some Member States of the European Union that they will not risk good relations with Canada because of us, that they will not risk jeopardizing their visa-free travel with Canada.I fully understand that, but in this case, I think we have the right to behave the same way again, and I do not think that it can be abused for some blackmail by the question of mutual loyalty.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, it is this resolution that I have supported.Precisely because, as the Czech Republic, we have experienced what Romania and Bulgaria are experiencing today with Canada.I think it is very important for states to work together on visa reciprocity.After all, it is not possible for people from third countries to travel to the European Union without a visa requirement, and at the same time some European citizens travel to these countries and have to obtain a visa.Unfortunately, this is currently the case in several countries, and we are depriving European citizens of their benefits.I therefore agree with this resolution and call on the European Commission to take all possible steps to eliminate this inequality in relations between the European Union and third countries.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, it is no coincidence that many of us Czech MEPs are in favor of visa reciprocity. After all, it was the Czech Republic that took the initiative in 2013 to approve Regulation No. 1289/2013, which imposes an obligation on the Commission to act in the area of ​​visa reciprocity. This deadline set by the regulation expired last April, and I am therefore convinced that the Commission has no discretion in this case. On the contrary, he is in a situation where he is not acting. I am therefore pleased that the visa requirement for Czech citizens for trips to Canada has been abolished in the meantime, and by the end of 2017, the visa requirement with Canada will also cease to apply to Bulgaria and Romania, also thanks to diplomatic work by the Commission. A visa reciprocity agreement with the United States is still in sight, and of course the United States has a new president and a new administration. Nevertheless, I think that the Commission should negotiate, it should negotiate with determination and confidence.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I also supported this proposal because, in my opinion, it is really about discriminating against European citizens.It is not possible to tolerate the creation of a dual level of European citizens in any way.The direction of our solidarity support for these states, which do not yet have a visa-free regime, is an absolute necessity so that we do not really create a double category of citizens.I also remember the period when the European Union was a bit inactive on the visas that were imposed on Czech citizens by Canada, but at the end of that period, as far as I know, we have already received support.And after four years, this visa requirement was ended.With today's vote, I wanted to express the same solidarity with colleagues from the countries concerned.Because the opposite procedure would be relatively Pharisaic on our part.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman! I abstained from endorsing the draft report on EU options for access to medicines, which, while appearing to be favorable, contains ambiguities and, in addition to those mentioned in the debate, calls for the consideration of new price control measures, such as horizontal observation and coordination of joint procurement, which may be subject to a new control regime. measures, but without further specification. The adoption of EU-wide pharmaceutical market measures, which would strengthen the negotiating positions of Member States to introduce fair prices for drugs, will be beneficial for countries with concerns, and the proposed directive regulating the procedures for establishing drugs and reimbursement systems may be beneficial for manufacturers at the expense of the health of patients, especially in countries such as Poland, where about 30% of patients do not buy drugs because of too high prices. Intellectual property laws have been found to hinder the introduction of generic drugs, both former and present, as an alternative for the less well-off.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the pharmaceutical sector has to deal with two important rights: the right to intellectual property and the right to health and treatment. However, public and private interests clash, the competition of products coming from the United States and Asia intervenes, huge economic profits, deeply affect in practice the real suffering of people. For the latter aspect more than for the others, it is therefore necessary to intervene as clearly as possible. Citizens must be guaranteed access to medicines at moderate prices and everyone's right to health must be protected and to do this research on new technologies and innovative medicines must also and above all be conducted by institutions. The European Union must reverse the trend in the prices of new medicines in recent years: they have grown to such an extent that they are prohibitive for many European citizens and unsustainable for health systems, given that pharmaceutical spending in Europe now represents 20% of expenditure. total health in the Member States.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, access to medicines falls within the scope of the protection of human rights, as also enshrined in the European Charter of Fundamental Rights. However, the high costs - including life-saving drugs - and the austerity policies that have hit the health sector, excluding millions of citizens from medical assistance, as happened for example in Greece and Spain, have deprived many European citizens of the possibility to access essential treatments and medicines for their health. Furthermore, there is a tendency to significantly decrease the obligations required of pharmaceutical companies on the tests to be provided for the approval of new medicines with smaller trials, control authorities not always independent from the influence or financing of companies and facilitated pathways for the marketing of drugs. There is therefore a prevalence of commercial logics and the citizen is considered a consumer rather than a subject whose right to health must be protected as a matter of priority. This right should be protected, not only with a view to access and an improved approach for the patient, but also with regard to the right to choose the tools, standards, approaches, therapies and drugs, including alternative ones, which should be equally guaranteed. This is why my vote is positive.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the European Union's health policy is supposed to focus on giving equal opportunities and access to medicines and at the same time quality healthcare to all. However, the policies of violent fiscal adjustment imposed in the Member States of the Union, and in particular in Greece, are increasingly affecting the health budgets of the Member States, threatening the safety of patients and the existing disparities in access to pharmaceuticals. care have been intensified. At the same time, in Greece the shortages of pediatric drugs and vaccines are serious. It is therefore necessary for the Union to take measures for equal access to health services and to combat the existing inequalities, while the shortages in medicines that are observed in Greece and especially in the Aegean islands should be immediately covered.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - We want access to medicines and access to essential therapies for life and innovative therapies.We want clear rules against incompatibility and against conflicts of interest and for transparency with regard to experts working in drug proceedings.It is unacceptable for people who make or decide policies on the drug market to be puppets of the big drug manufacturers.We do not want drug trafficking, we want to stop the export of medicines.For example, in Romania, medicines that cost thousands of euros are settled, but disappear on the black market.Distribution companies buy very cheap certain drugs and sell them in pharmacies in Europe where the allowed price is ten times higher.Thus, drugs never reach the sick again.We have an underground industry that violates the right to life and we have a responsibility to stop that.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I supported this report, but at the same time I add that medicines policy is a matter for the individual Member States.I am not in favor of adopting any new legislation and regulating this sector.If colleagues are talking here about the financial availability of medicines in some countries, then it is the problem of those specific countries.The European Union can hardly solve this.On the other hand, and I consider this to be positive, I think that the European Union can support and strengthen research into some demanding medicines, which are either not commercially attractive or individual research in individual countries does not have enough money for them.I think it makes sense to concentrate funding at European level and to support research and development into certain medicines.In my opinion, this is the added value of this report, which is why I supported it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, I also supported this European Parliament report because I consider cooperation between Member States in protecting public health to be very beneficial.Of course, this is not some necessary mutual regulation, but really cooperation, especially in the area of exchanging information and best practices.There is also a need for cooperation in research investment, especially in the development of drugs for rare diseases, where investment in research by commercial operators is insufficient.I also consider it necessary for the obligation to ensure the supply of medicines to be extended not only to distributors but also to manufacturers who supply distributors.However, the protection of human health cannot be reduced to drug policy alone.It must also focus on prevention and a healthy lifestyle and responsible use of medicines.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I also supported this report. In my opinion, it is very important to support research, development, innovation and, of course, the exchange of information in the field of medicines policy. A lot has already been said about this here from colleagues, I join it. However, I would like to mention one more aspect that has not been mentioned here, and that is the issue of transparency, precisely in the area of ​​pricing policy. This is very important, because it very often happens that if an expensive drug is replaced by a certain generic, then this replacement is very often accompanied by a dispute arising from competition, unfair competition, protection of intellectual property rights. Undoubtedly, these disputes make it very expensive to market these drug substitutes and, as a result, they make medicines and their availability more expensive. We should try to prevent this by defining a precise legal framework for possible intellectual property disputes.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - I have already announced my support for this report in the debate.However, I cannot fail to draw attention here to the issue of re-exports, which in some Member States lead to a shortage of medicines for domestic patients.The combination of the single market and the different prices of medicines, which are based on the financial capabilities of each country's health insurance system, often makes it advantageous for distribution companies to buy a medicine in one Member State and sell it in another.Fortunately, the treaties provide for an exception to the prohibition of agreements restricting competition.However, it is for the Court to decide how it interprets it in relation to measures on the market in medicinal products.I am aware that public health insurance solidarity systems in the Member States differ.Nevertheless, I can't help but feel that this problem requires a systemic solution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming years, the health systems of the European Union will have to face major challenges such as the aging of the population, the increasingly heavy burden of chronic diseases, the significant cost of developing new technologies, effects of the economic crisis on health expenditure. Healthcare is a fundamental right of European citizens, but insufficient access to essential medicines and the high prices of innovative medicines pose a serious threat to the sustainability of national healthcare systems. Added to this is the poor link between clinical needs and research, patent rules, budgetary restrictions, unjustified administrative procedures, long intervals between marketing authorizations. The increase in expenditure in the pharmaceutical sector, as well as the asymmetries observed in the capacity for negotiating prices between pharmaceutical companies and Member States, therefore make it necessary to strengthen European cooperation and the adoption of new measures to ensure greater ease for all European citizens. access to medicines, which is why I voted in favor of this report.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - (The first part of the speech was not recorded due to a technical problem.) Mr President, Hungary, my country, joined the European Union thirteen years ago. Compared to this, there are still tens of thousands of pensioners who have a monthly pension of around HUF 50,000, ie less than EUR 200, and have basic livelihood problems. Under these circumstances, I would have found it repulsive to vote for such a completely confusing Creative Europe program, which, let us pay attention to how much it has a budget of: EUR 1.46 billion. If we count in HUF, multiply this number by three hundred, so much will be spent on Creative Europe, and what it hides on page 25. In the light of the significant influx of migrants and refugees into the EU in recent years, it welcomes the fact that the program is becoming increasingly intercultural. which will hopefully increase the number of projects promoting cultural diversity, intercultural dialogue and multilingualism from 2017, given that integration in many Member States is likely to be a leap in the coming years. Let these funds be reallocated to normalize living standards in Central Europe.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with a simple sentence, the rapporteur, Mrs Costa, whom I thank, expresses clearly and synthetically the situation of the "Creative Europe" program which - says Mr Costa - suffers from its own success. Basically, too many questions, too many projects, too many expectations, too much effort, for such a limited budget. Sometimes, projects are excluded only for a 0%, too many projects are presented and this can only make us happy. Through the "Creative Europe" program, European citizens demonstrate their liveliness and imagination. However, financing only 15% of projects - and this is the percentage - risks discouraging the contenders: industries, associations, civil society, which believe in these projects, of high European value. There are not many other sources of funding for culture. I therefore agree with my colleague's appeal and I hope that in the next budget there will actually be more space for those who build Europe with ideas, rather than numbers.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! I supported this report for two reasons. Firstly, because the bureaucracy that limited the possibilities of this program was reduced, but also because the payment arrears, which were a serious drawback in the implementation of the Creative Europe program, were eliminated. However, I would like to point out one thing on this occasion. New initiatives appear from time to time - I'm not talking about pilot programs, but rather about the European Year of Heritage for 2018 - and I want to make it clear that looking for funds in the Creative Europe program to finance such one-year-dedicated projects is a serious mistake . I would like the "Creative Europe" program, if it already exists, to be well dedicated, and not be such a resource for various new initiatives, because it simply weakens it, weakens the prestige of the European Commission and weakens also all the elements that make up such dedicated programs.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I supported this Creative Europe program, which frees up money for certain transnational cultural projects. I think it is certainly good if, without adopting any European legislation, we support certain cultural projects that do not only concern specific countries, but concern, say, a larger territory. For example, I know from my colleague, Mrs Šojdrová, that a large exhibition entitled "Broken Time" is being prepared in the Czech Republic in Olomouc, which will map the artistic culture of the Central European phenomenon. It will show the differences and, conversely, the common faces of the fine arts of the Visegrad Four countries and Central European countries in general. This is an example of a project that should also be supported by European money, because only, for example, national money would not create such a project. So I welcome that, and it is good that the material itself addresses the issue of administrative simplification and removes some unnecessary problematic barriers that complicate the release of money for specific projects.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Mr President, I did not hesitate to support this report, as it provides many suggestions on how to increase the effectiveness of the Creative Europe program, following previous systematic monitoring of its implementation to date.The main problem that needs to be addressed is the lack of quality management of the entire program, which brings with it a very low number of supported projects.One example for all, in my opinion, is very alarming, especially the extremely low success rate of refugee integration projects.This rate is less than five percent.Furthermore, I think that everything must be done to maximize the effectiveness of the whole program, including increasing its transparency, simplifying communication between the various actors and making it more visible within the Member States of the European Union.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that today's resolution goes in the right direction, that of being able to guarantee the possibility of implementing this program in the best possible way, a program that guarantees the possibility of transferring the competitive advantage of our Europe to all territories andto ensure that this competitive advantage, in an increasingly globalized world, sees our businesses, our companies have one more chance, one based on culture, innovation and above all on that great heritage we have of history, aheritage that is unique in the world and that makes us increasingly competitive.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr President, another great program that I did not vote for because I find it outrageous: this program has a budget of EUR 185 million 468 000, and the subject will, I am surprised, most of the selected projects deal with migration, social inclusion and deals with topics related to intercultural issues. But the joke comes only after the report and the program itself, this small program with a modest budget, is entitled 'Europe for Citizens', and in point (c) on page 29 it says that the campaign for the Europe for Citizens program aims to send a strong, symbolic message about listening to the voices of European citizens. Well, congratulations from the bottom of my heart, I managed to hear the voices of European citizens very well, it would be very good if they would try a little more and say the voices of Hungarian pensioners, nurses and firefighters.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!Europe for Citizens is not just the name of the program, it is a goal, it is a great and wonderful idea that we have been implementing for several decades and I am convinced that this program has never been so important and should not be treated as seriously as it is now.Now, when Europe, when the European Union is on a bend, is on the bend, now when we are discussing politicians among ourselves, but we should also discuss between us politicians and the citizens of Europe what the future should be for our continent, but above all for our community - this program should be for ushelp in this.However, of course, while implementing this program, including its finances, we should take into account that the world is changing and that nowadays we are dealing not only with this real world, but also with the virtual world, and in this other world we should also very responsibly discuss with citizens.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - In this time of crisis, the Europe for Citizens program strengthens the sense of citizenship and solidarity that we so desperately need at this time of crossroads for the European Union. Funding for this program has unfortunately been reduced by over 13% and this is an obstacle, it has been and is an obstacle for several organizations whose projects have been rejected precisely due to lack of funds. This program has the potential to come up with solutions to problems and questions and things that are not going well in the European Union. We just discussed yesterday the options for the future of the European Union, they range from, how to say, from zero to ten or from minus to plus, and we need to consult with European citizens when making these decisions. We want to bring European citizens to the European Union. There are no two parallel worlds, the European Union separately, the citizens separately, but we represent citizens.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! I support the Europe for Citizens program with one serious doubt. It should be remembered and remembered that in 2015 only 33 applications out of more than half a thousand were approved. This means that over half a thousand different types of potential beneficiaries, associations and foundations were dismissed with no money. I remember the debate on this particular program, in which a voice appeared to justify the refusal to finance a specific project. I imagine what the rationale would be: simply lack of resources. However, I support this program for one more important reason. Well, it also includes the information policy of the European Parliament, and it is far from perfect. I believe that all projects that make the youngest generation aware of all the issues dealt with in the European Parliament, by the European institution and serve Europe as such, must be supported.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - Mr President, we are voting here with iron regularity on reports that pour public money, taxpayers' money, into various propaganda - and I dare say ideologically - motivated projects.It is one of them, the one we are discussing right now.I have never supported, I do not support and I will not support anything, because I do not think that it is possible to create a common European public opinion or a European nation or a European consciousness with some artificial methods and programs of this type.This, if it can arise at all, must arise in some evolutionary way, evolve naturally, and cannot be dogmatically determined by any similar program.It seems to me to be an unnecessary waste of taxpayers' money, and I think that the European Parliament is making the mistake of repeatedly supporting such programs at all.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, I supported this program because, as a person involved in regional and municipal policy, I am well aware of the importance and benefit of cities communicating within the European Union, when children from different schools go on exchanges. to other cities within another state of the European Union. I perceive it as very good when athletes and other hobby clubs from individual cities work together in this way. Among other things, this is what this program is about, which supports the so-called partnership of cities, which is not about creating a common ideology or creating a common European nation here. It is about civil society people from individual cities at local level making friends and comrades and interacting with people from another city from another European Union country and thus gaining information about their partners, neighbors from other European Union countries in a natural, unforced way. . That, I think, is right, that it is worth supporting and that it is not an imperative or a bureaucracy.

name: Notis MARIAS

Moreover, while the "Europe for Citizens" program ostensibly refers to historical memory, it does not talk about the war reparations that Germany owes to Greece, due to the First and Second World Wars.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the "Europe for Citizens" project reached record figures in the period 2007-2013, with 7 million direct participants and over 400 civil society organizations involved. If the aim was to bring the European Union closer to its citizens, the result has been extremely encouraging. In light of the restructuring of the program and with the idea of ​​making it even more effective, I believe that the financing of projects aimed at creating a European memory must feed more directly on the aspirations and values ​​of the new generations. Indeed, if Europe is being questioned today, it is precisely because its greatness has not been fully told. The story that unites us - which unites all of us, even in this House - should not be used only as a warning and should not be reduced to a sequence of dramas and conflicts, its value is in the experience and dialogue between generations. For these reasons, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, I agree with the rapporteur that the budget for the Europe for Citizens program is unjustifiably low. It would not be too hasty for the Commission to adopt a level of EUR 1 per citizen when setting the budget for the next program, which is still only EUR 500 million. The importance of the program has increased, especially with the enlargement of the EU to the east. I come from an eastern Member State and I know for sure that 40 years of communism have not passed without a trace in our societies, we cannot pretend that we no longer feel the effects of this period. Western Europe has had just as much time to overcome historical grievances as we have, and the clear intention of the founding Member States has strengthened this process. Today’s Central and Eastern Europe and the Western Balkans need this: historical reconciliation, a common processing of the past and the building of mutual trust. Therefore, this program is very important, please treat it accordingly.
